HEADLINE: World Briefing Europe: France: LaFayette, We Are Leery

BYLINE: By Ariane Bernard (NYT)

 BODY:
The level of trust between the French and Americans is at its lowest in 17 years, according to a poll published by Le Monde. The survey of 1,000 people in each country, carried out by the polling firm TNS Sofres, found that only 31 percent of the French had ''sympathy'' for Americans, down from 39 percent in September 2002. About 35 percent of American respondents said they liked the French, down from 50 percent in September 2002. The survey also showed that both French and American respondents' views had changed on whether the two countries were partners or adversaries: only 39 percent of the French respondents believe that the United States and France are first and foremost partners, down from 50 percent in September 2002, while 45 percent of Americans see the two countries as partners, a sharp drop from 68 percent in September 2002. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

HEADLINE: At Paris Air Show, Yachts That Fly

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: LE BOURGET, France, June 16 

 BODY:
Despite an hourlong wait under rainy skies, visitors flocked to see Bombardier's luxurious private jet, the Global 5000, which was on display this week at the Paris Air Show here, looking a bit like a Porsche parked among Volkswagens.
 Dry and cozy inside, potential buyers tried the wireless entertainment system, ran their hands over the polished wood trim and listened to Bombardier's sales representatives explain why the visitors just had to own this $35 million airplane. (Among other things, it is speedy, flying from Chicago to Paris in less time than it takes Gulfstream's rival G450 to fly from Chicago to London.)
 The market for business jets is booming again, after a steep downdraft following the collapse of technology stocks in 2000. Sales jumped 18 percent in 2004 over the previous year, and they are continuing this year at a double-digit pace, thanks to the buoyant American economy, which has fattened corporate profits and personal bank accounts. 
 ''This is a feast-or-famine business,'' said James Hoblyn, the vice president for Bombardier's business aircraft division, before dashing off to a customer meeting in search of his next meal.
 As the orders flow in, some entrepreneurs are trying to stretch the definition of private jets -- both upward and downward. The Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass was here to promote his plans for a supersonic corporate jet from his Aerion Corporation. Vern Raburn, a former Microsoft executive and the chief executive of Eclipse Aviation, was talking up his cheap -- well, $1.3 million -- private jet, which he says will be used as an airborne taxi.
 ''In some ways, our companies share characteristics,'' said Mr. Raburn, who says he has 2,200 orders for his plane. ''We're both trying to do the same thing, which is to save people's time.''
 Surprisingly, perhaps, some analysts give the supersonic jet better odds of success than the shoestring one. In recent years, sales of large jets, some costing close to $50 million, have been more robust than entry-level models. Like yachts, the size of cruise ships or resort-scale beach houses, fancy planes have become a totem of success among the extremely rich.
 ''It's the growing gap between the incredible, out-of-sight wealthy and the merely rich that drives this market,'' said Richard L. Aboulafia, vice president for research at the Teal Group, an aerospace concern in Fairfax, Va.
 Brian E. Barents, the vice chairman of Mr. Bass's venture, said the demand for supersonic jets would be driven, at least in part, by status and one-upmanship. ''We benefit from the 'my toy is bigger than your toy' phenomenon,'' he said.
 In this case, of course, the toy is not bigger but faster. Aerion's plan is to build a needle-nose, eight-seat aircraft able to fly 1.6 times the speed of sound while over water, and just under the sound barrier over land. That would permit it to fly within the United States, where regulations prohibit supersonic civilian planes because of their sonic booms.
 Aerion has tested its design and is seeking commercial partners to build the jet, with a goal of delivering the first one around 2011. The company thinks it can price the plane at close to $80 million, and still compete with slower jets from Gulfstream or Bombardier.
 Bombardier, which vies with Gulfstream as the largest maker of business jets, says it is not worried about losing buyers who yearn for their own Concorde, whose last flight was October 2003. ''A bunch of our customers would love to fly at supersonic speeds,'' Mr. Hoblyn said. ''But I have trouble with the business case.''
 Any supersonic jet, he noted, will have a cramped cabin not unlike that in the Concorde. The Global 5000 is spacious, with ample headroom and enough floor space to create two cabins, one with a divan that can be used for naps.
 Mr. Barents replies by quoting Bill Lear, a corporate-jet pioneer, who once said of his snug Learjet, ''You can't stand up in a Cadillac, either.''
 People are already willing to pay large premiums for faster versions of existing planes, Mr. Barents said, like the popular Cessna Citation 10. The Aerion jet will be able to fly from New York to Tokyo in 9 hours, 33 minutes, including a one-hour fuel stop in Anchorage. That compares with 14 hours, 21 minutes nonstop in a standard subsonic airliner.
 ''There's been a void in the marketplace since the Concorde retired,'' Mr. Barents said. ''We have an old saying in this industry: higher, faster, farther. Well, no one is going faster right now.''
 Mr. Raburn sees a void in the marketplace, too. But he thinks it is on the lower end, among people who would pay for the convenience of using a private jet from time to time, but do not want to own one, or even a share in one -- the fractional ownership model pioneered by NetJets.
 His company, Eclipse Aviation, based in Albuquerque, has built a six-seat jet that will sell for $1.3 million. In inflation-adjusted dollars, that is less than half the price of the first Learjet, introduced in the early 1960's. 
 Mr. Raburn says it will create a market for air taxis: services that send a plane to an outlying airport when a customer requests a flight.
 Last month, Eclipse signed its first deal with an air-taxi service, DayJet, for 239 planes over five years. DayJet says it will be able to charge people only slightly more than a full-fare economy ticket.
 Mr. Raburn, who helped Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft billionaire, choose the Boeing 757 he uses as a private plane, sees a limit to the hunger for extravagant jets.
 ''There isn't anything more ostentatious and extreme than a G550,'' Gulfstream's top model, he said,.
 ''Our market,'' he said, ''is the merely rich guys who are looking for convenience in business travel. They're the ones who will pay $500 more to take a corporate jet rather than a commercial flight.''

HEADLINE: Treasury Yields Rise Again, Spurring Talk of a Trend

BYLINE: By RIVA D. ATLAS

 BODY:
What goes down must come up. 
 That is the logic behind the hopes of many traders this week that a rise in yields on 10-year Treasury notes will stick, reversing a recent decline that has even Alan Greenspan scratching his head.
 Yields on the Treasury notes ended the week slightly higher at 4.07 percent, compared with 4.05 percent a week earlier. This is the second consecutive week of rising yields, reversing a long decline that culminated in yields sinking to a 52-week low of 3.89 percent on June 1. 
 The rising yields came amid a series of encouraging economic reports that also contributed to a surge in stock prices. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended the week up 18.85 points, or 1.57 percent, to 1,216.96. Yesterday's six-point climb erased prior losses for the index for the year, with the S.&P. now showing a modest 0.42 percent gain for the year. The Nasdaq composite index rose 27.11 points, or 1.31 percent, to close at 2,090.11, while the Dow rose 110.47 points, or 1.05 percent, to 10,623.07. The Dow and the Nasdaq continue to show losses for the year, 1.48 percent and 3.92 percent, respectively.
 But even as some analysts hailed the recent market shifts, skeptics said that lingering uncertainties about the economy could drive Treasury yields -- and stock prices -- back down over the next few months.
 Yields have been dropping on Treasuries, even as the Federal Reserve has been raising short-term interest rates. That has baffled traders, with many investment banks suffering trading losses last quarter amid the steep decline. Mr. Greenspan in a speech earlier this year referred to the depressed yields as a ''conundrum.''
 Prices for Treasury bonds, which move in the opposite direction from yields, fell this week amid several positive indicators on the economy, culminating in yesterday's bullish report from the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey. 
 A stronger economy generally leads to higher stock prices, and makes the safe haven of Treasury bonds less attractive to investors. Lower Treasury yields typically lead to reduced mortgage rates.
 ''The good news about the economy offset the bad news of short-term interest rates continuing to head higher,'' said Hugh A. Johnson Jr., chief investment officer of Johnson Illington Advisors, a money management firm based in Albany.
 ''The message is that this economic cycle has longer to go,'' a sign that stock prices are likely to rise, but Treasury yields will, too, he said.
 When Lehman Brothers reported its earnings on Tuesday, its chief administrative officer, David Goldfarb, predicted that Treasury yields would reach 4.7 percent by year's end.
 Still, analysts pointed to several lingering worries, any of which could cause the economy, and the direction of the markets, to reverse. These include a bursting of the bubble in housing prices, a significant slowdown in the Chinese economy, and the rising price of oil, which closed at $58.47 a barrel this week.
 The continued uncertainty about the direction of the economy, and bond prices, was apparent on Thursday, when the Federal Reserve's Philadelphia branch reported an unexpected decline in its manufacturing index. Yields on Treasuries dropped slightly to 4.069 percent. Yields were essentially unchanged at 4.07 percent yesterday, despite the positive economic report.
 Some large bond fund managers are still not confident that in the long term, yields will head much higher. 
 ''Everyone has been calling for higher yields for months, and they have all been wrong,'' said James Keller, who oversees $100 billion worth of government bond investments for Pimco, the giant bond fund manager. 
 Jeffrey Gundlach, president of the TCW Asset Management Company, which manages $80 billion in portfolios for pension funds and other institutions, said, ''We got to a situation where Treasuries were overbought.'' While yields could move higher in the short term, he says they will remain well below 5 percent.
 A year after the Fed began raising short-term interest rates, Mr. Gundlach says the Fed is two-thirds through the process. Sometime in the six months, he said, the Fed will stop raising rates, setting the stage for it to reverse course, and begin lowering rates, sometime next year. A decline in short-term rates would probably lead to a drop in longer-term bond yields as well, he said.
 Investors will also probably remain attracted to the Treasury market, despite the relatively low yields. A report this week indicating a lower-than-expected increase amount of debt purchased by foreigners was not significant enough to presage a long-term decline, Mr. Gundlach said. 
 He also pointed to weak returns this year for hedge funds, which are investment partnerships for wealthy individuals and large institutions like pension funds. Those funds on average are returning less than 1 percent so far this year.
 But other investors continue to anticipate a prolonged reversal in Treasury yields. Mr. Johnson said that, despite the uncertainties, he believes that yields will continue to rise. ''I believe we will muddle through,'' he said. ''But I have my fingers tightly crossed.''

HEADLINE: The Train! The Train!

BYLINE: By Gene Russianoff. 
Gene Russianoff is a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group's Straphangers Campaign.

 BODY:
THIS week, in the wake of the failed West Side stadium project, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg agreed to help the Mets and the Yankees build new ballparks that could be used if New York City wins its bid for the 2012 Olympics. Those projects may have their good points, but Mr. Bloomberg has neglected a project that would have a far greater impact: the Second Avenue subway line. 
 The best way to revive Lower Manhattan -- and give a boost to Midtown -- is to build a subway line that carries people from Harlem and the East Side to work downtown. This would be a wonderfully appropriate way to spend 9/11 funds. 
 A Second Avenue subway line would better the lives of about 600,000 riders by giving them another transportation option and relieving crowded conditions on the Lexington Avenue line. Right now, the Lexington Avenue's three lines, the No.'s 4, 5 and 6, carry 40 percent of the 23-line system's riders. The crowded trains are an ordeal for rush-hour riders and a disincentive for businesses to move downtown. 
 The project would also make good economic sense. According to the Regional Plan Association, the new line would offer time and trip savings of $1.26 billion a year -- that's in addition to the 70,000 construction jobs it would generate. 
 Sadly, the project is in some financial peril. The ''minimum operating segment,'' as the federal government calls the first phase of the Second Avenue subway line, would attract hundreds of thousands of people. (This is the stretch that would go from Harlem to Midtown and then on to Brooklyn through an existing line.) But the $3.6 billion first phase needs about $2.5 billion to be completed in the next seven years, and unfortunately Albany didn't allocate enough money for the first phase in the most recent state budget.
 As a result, a dangerous idea is now afloat: additional borrowing. This would saddle the subway's seven million daily riders with higher fares and deeper cuts, resulting in more maintenance problems. 
 Thankfully, there's a smart way out. Instead of borrowing, let's use 9/11 federal funds for the Second Avenue line. And there's precedent. New centers for the PATH trains and the South Ferry terminal are already using terrorist recovery funds and work will begin soon on a federally financed transit center at the Fulton Street and Broadway-Nassau stations. 
 But for the Second Avenue subway to happen, Mayor Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki need to become stronger champions for the project. 
 Here's what the mayor should do. The City of New York gives only $75 million a year to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's general repair program. For 20 years, the city gave $100 million to $200 million annually. The city is flusher today and more money could go to stations like two downtown Chambers Street stations, dropped from the authority's repair program. Other decrepit stations, including those in Bensonhurst and Forest Hills, could also benefit.
 The governor's first step should be to direct $80 million of 9/11 funds to the Cortlandt Street station. Although it was the only subway station destroyed in the collapse of the twin towers, its restoration would be inexplicably borne by the riding public, through the system's general repair program.
 Some argue that it would be hard to make the case in Washington for a Second Avenue subway getting Sept. 11 funds. But conventional wisdom is often wrong. 
 New York shows over and over again that victory can be snatched from defeat. Supporters of the Westway project, which would have created a highway through landfill under the environmentally sensitive waters of the Hudson River, lament its 1985 failure. But they neglect to mention the $1.4 billion its trade-in raised for new subway cars at a critical time. And for years, downtown was told that there was going to be a four-block, $860 million West Street tunnel next to ground zero, but after years of local protest and business objections, this boondoggle has been abandoned and some $500 million to $600 million of federal 9/11 funds are now up for grabs. 
 What more fitting recipient for 9/11 funds is there than a subway to downtown that helps New Yorkers get back to work?

HEADLINE: Quarterly Trade Gap Hits $195 Billion

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17 

 BODY:
The United States hit a record deficit of $195.1 billion in the first quarter in trade and capital flows with the rest of the world, the Commerce Department reported Friday. The news reignited worries that the economy cannot sustain the growing level of global debt.
 If this pace continues, the United States' current account deficit could reach $780 billion this year, a sharp increase from last year's record of $617 billion.
 The United States continued to attract foreign investments at relatively low interest rates, and the rate of growth in the trade imbalance has slowed. But the direction remains the same, and the overall current account deficit now stands at a 6.4 percent of gross domestic product, also a record. 
 ''Clearly the current account deficit can't go on like this forever,'' said Daniel T. Griswold, director of the Cato Institute's center for trade policy studies, a conservative research group that has generally not worried about the United States' trade gap. 
 Economists agree that the drop in the value of the dollar is only beginning to help redress the trade imbalance, in part because China and Japan are enjoying what they see as significantly undervalued currencies. The Bush administration has been pressing China and other Asian nations to revalue their currencies. 
 The White House, in general, sees the widening current-account deficit as a sign of strength in the United States and weakness elsewhere. 
 ''It shows overwhelmingly that the United States economy is showing remarkable strength compared to our European trading partners and generating a lot more income for Americans to buy a lot more foreign goods,'' said Tony Fratto, a Treasury Department spokesman.
 According to this analysis, the responsibility for altering the trade imbalance lies with Europe and Japan, not the United States. Those foreign economies, officials argue, have to restructure their economies and start buying more American goods and consume more of what they produce domestically.
 Rob Portman, the United States trade representative, met with Peter Mandelson, his European counterpart, on Friday ahead of the United States-European summit meeting on Monday. Both men tried to shift the emphasis away from recent trade disputes, like the lawsuits over subsidies paid to Boeing and Airbus, and instead promote the effectiveness of the overall trade relationship.
 ''We have so much in common,'' Mr. Portman said.
 He was followed by Mr. Mandelson who said that the two men ''had not only a very constructive meeting but a very enjoyable meeting.''
 Both men said they were still open to a negotiated settlement in the long-simmering dispute over government subsidies to Boeing and Airbus. Formal discussions on an agreement broke down last month, and both sides filed cases with the World Trade Organization. While the two officials did not rule out a deal, they offered few specifics about any talks.
 ''The channels of communication between us are open,'' Mr. Mandelson said. 
 In the meantime, however, the United States borrows, in essence, $2.1 billion every day to keep the economy afloat, according to the calculations of Stuart Hoffman, chief economist at PNC.
 Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, said the deficit figure was reaching ''dangerous levels that are hurting this country's future.''
 ''This deficit manifests itself in the lives of American families every day with the loss of jobs overseas, lower wages and a feeling of less security,'' Mr. Dorgan contended. 
 Several economists said that while the figures remain disappointing, one of the reasons for the unexpectedly wide gap was a $3.3 billion increase in aid to other countries, in part a reflection of the relief sent to Southeast Asia after the tsunami hit last December.
 ''It's nothing to be cheerful about, but the magnitude of the relief payments and donations holds the potential to distort these figures,'' said Mark Vitner, a senior economist at Wachovia in Charlotte, N.C.
 Many economists say the United States should save more and spend less, especially the federal government. Mr. Griswold of Cato said nothing in the budget should be immune from serious cuts, including the military budget and entitlements.
 But Robert E. Scott, senior analyst at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research group, said that it was ''ludicrous to think the deficit is caused by a shortfall in savings.''
 The deficit, he said, is caused by the nation's voracious appetite for foreign goods and its inability to sell enough overseas to balance those purchases. ''Just to keep the gap from growing, exports would have to increase 78 percent faster than they actually did,'' Mr. Scott said. ''That's the bad news; the wider the gap, the more difficult it is to turn this economy around.''
 The argument about the cause of these deficits is spilling over into the debate over the Central American Free Trade Agreement, the centerpiece of the administration's trade agenda this year. Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, the Maryland Democrat and ranking member of the trade subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee, said on Friday that the soaring deficit showed the administration's trade strategy was failing.
 ''It says we are still hemorrhaging,'' Mr. Cardin said. ''We are still moving in the wrong direction and the size of the deficit raises serious questions about our ability to control our own destiny.''

LENGTH: 901 words

HEADLINE: G.M.'s Small-Car Glass Is Now Half Full

BYLINE: By JEFF SABATINI

 BODY:
I HAVE yet to read the headline, ''Vultures Circle Renaissance Center,'' but as the bad news has multiplied with each passing week, certainly a member of the press must have been assigned to bird-watching duty at General Motors' global headquarters in Detroit. 
 Not a day has gone by in the past month that has not brought some pundit's proclamations of G.M.'s impending demise. A confluence of events -- from slowing S.U.V. sales to multiple debt-rating downgrades, the meddling of the financier Kirk Kerkorian and the announcement of more plant closings and layoffs -- has darkened skies over Detroit. But if a ray of sunshine exists, it is this: Despite the legions of truly awful products G.M. has built in the past three decades, its newest models are vastly improved and generally likable. 
 The compact Chevrolet Cobalt, for instance, hints at a brighter future. It will eventually replace the despicable Cavalier in Chevy's lineup (for the time being, 2005 models of both cars are crowding dealer lots), slotting between the subcompact Aveo and midsize Malibu. The Cobalt is a good car, if not a great one, and it is certainly a creditable competitor to the Toyota Corolla, Honda Civic and most other $15,000 cars on the market. 
 The Cobalt's base price, including shipping, is $14,190, although under G.M.'s current ''Employee Discount for Everyone'' promotion (which runs through July 5), this number drops to $12,471. As low as those numbers sound, it is possible to push the price of a Cobalt beyond $20,000.
 Available as a front-wheel-drive sedan or coupe, the Cobalt is powered by a 2.2-liter version of G.M.'s Ecotec 4-cylinder engine that produces 145 horsepower and 155 pound-feet of torque. Those are good numbers for this segment -- Toyota's standard Corolla has a 1.8-liter 4-cylinder with 130 horsepower and 125 pound-feet of torque -- and the Cobalt hustles around pretty well, even when equipped with an optional four-speed automatic transmission.
 There is a price to be paid for those horses, however, as an automatic Cobalt sedan is rated at 24 miles a gallon in the city and 32 on the highway by the Environmental Protection Agency. The Corolla's numbers are better by six miles a gallon in both situations, in large part because it is lighter; the Corolla weighs in about 275 pounds less than the 2,868-pound Cobalt.
 The Cobalt's suspension and steering are better than most cars in this class. G.M. has hit a sweet spot for cheap-car ride, achieving a nice compromise between cushy and responsive. The Cobalt did not sway me from my belief that the Mazda 3 is the best-handling compact car extant, nor was its steering as taut as that of the Ford Focus, but many drivers will prefer the Chevy's softer ride and slightly overassisted steering.
 Though both Cobalt body styles are attractive, the coupe is the shapelier car, just as it should be. Its long hood and short trunk lid recall classic muscle car proportions, but this is no exercise in retro styling, as its sloping rear window and wraparound fascias front and rear are thoroughly modern. While its round tail lamps do nod to Chevrolets past, the coupe's tough rear end could just as easily be mistaken for that of a Ferrari 360 Modena. Squint too long at the Cobalt sedan, however, and you might mistake it for a 2005 Volkswagen Jetta.
 G.M.'s design team has captured the essence of Chevy styling in the Cobalt, taking an inoffensively generic car shape, making its lines crisp and simple, then ornamenting it with just a few interesting details. The approach carries over to the interior, which is thankfully utilitarian, generally comfortable and only embarrassing when clad with chintzy accents of fake wood. Fortunately, metal-look trim is optional.
 Regardless of how the cabin is dressed up, the materials are of good enough quality and seem to be well assembled. All Cobalts have a good-looking gauge package with a display that reports fuel economy and outside temperature among other functions, a nice touch for a car in this price class.
 The Cobalt's safety rating is a concern, as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration gave the sedan only two stars (out of a maximum of five) for its performance in front-seat side-impact testing. This was an improvement over the Cavalier, which earned only one star in the same test. 
 In other government tests, the Cobalt did better, scoring fours and fives. But basic safety features like antilock brakes and traction control are optional on base models and side curtain air bags cost extra on all levels of the Cobalt.
 My other issues with the car are less serious. Its exhaust tone could be improved; either quieter or louder would be preferable to sounding like a vacuum cleaner. The coupe's trunk opening is too small, a problem that could have been rectified, and should have been, by making the car a hatchback. 
 When all is said and done, nothing about the Cobalt is truly outstanding, just as nothing is egregiously wrong. In this competitive market segment, it stands as a solid effort, though it is not likely to win any car of the year awards. Still, G.M. has not sold a good small car since it last hawked the Prizm, a Chevy-badged version of the Toyota Corolla that disappeared in 2002. That the Cobalt is a true G.M. product says that this beleaguered company may indeed have a chance.

INSIDE TRACK: May Chevy never have to speak of the Cavalier again.

Other recent books of particular interest

STEINBERG AT THE NEW YORKER, by Joel Smith. (Abrams, $50.) Eighty-nine covers and many, many other drawings by the fantastically inventive artist from a dinky Romanian town.

THE POWER OF DELIGHT. A Lifetime in Literature: Essays 1962-2002, by John Bayley. (Norton, $29.95.) This cagey, generous critic knows how to break down the barriers between difficult writers and ordinary readers.

BOOKING PASSAGE: We Irish and Americans, by Thomas Lynch. (Norton, $24.95.) The poet and undertaker from Michigan draws spiritual vigor from the homeland he now knows well.

HEADLINE: Alison Birch, Joshua Sullivan

 BODY:
Alison Marie Birch, the daughter of Barbara and Adrian L. Birch of Manalapan, N.J., was married yesterday to Joshua Patrick Sullivan, a son of Jean and Daniel J. Sullivan of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. 
James R. Covington, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the New York Academy of Sciences. 
 The couple received M.B.A. degrees from New York University, where they met.
 Mrs. Sullivan, 28, is an associate at Standard & Poor's, the rating agency in New York; she analyzes corporate credit ratings. She graduated cum laude from Boston College. Her father is a vice president for drug regulatory affairs at Novartis, the pharmaceutical company, in East Hanover, N.J. Her mother is retiring this month as a language arts teacher at the Pine Brook School in Manalapan.
 Mr. Sullivan, 30, is an associate at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm in New York; he provides management consulting services to clients. He graduated from Cornell. His mother retired as a guidance counselor at Southwest High School in Minneapolis. His father holds the Cowles Chair of Media Management and Economics at the School of Journalism and Mass Communication at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 42

LENGTH: 5222 words

HEADLINE: Movement

BYLINE: By Arthur Lubow. 
Arthur Lubow, a contributing writer, last wrote for the magazine about the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami.

 BODY:
Clive Gillinson transformed himself from musician into manager at a moment of crisis. In 1984, the London Symphony Orchestra was more than $600,000 in debt and sinking. The orchestra moved two years earlier into the Barbican Center, a mazelike modern-arts complex located in the City, the financial district, which in those days shut down after dark. In that confusing and out-of-the-way destination, the orchestra administration programmed unorthodox concerts (a festival of Berlioz and Michael Tippett, for example) in tightly clustered stretches. Each Barbican concert lost an average of $3,000. An orchestra that is governed by its players, the L.S.O. reacted to this desperate plight with an act of desperation. It forced out its managing director and, looking within the ranks, recruited Gillinson, a young cellist whose chief business credential was running an antiques shop with his wife in his spare time. Before accepting, the prudent cellist insisted that his chair in the orchestra be kept open for a year in case the new job didn't work out. Just as characteristically, however, he never looked back. 
 Within two years, the L.S.O. had balanced its books, and Gillinson was charging ahead. ''He's been one of the most decisive figures on the cultural scene generally, someone who has made a really distinctive change in the stature of his organization over the years,'' says Nicholas Kenyon, director of the BBC Proms summer classical music festival. Gillinson never lost sight of his long-range goals. Even while he was piling on lackluster commercial gigs to pay the bills, he periodically presented ambitious programs to secure the L.S.O.'s reputation. As the financial crisis abated, he raised the stakes. In the past few years, he has started an in-house recording label and opened a state-of-the-art education center. To do so, he needed to persuade the musicians to back financially risky undertakings that offered no short-term payoffs. In the hidebound world of classical music, the slightest deviation from traditional procedure is usually regarded as unsupportable heresy. Somehow, Gillinson got away with it. ''He was very inventive, and he was always finding money,'' says Pierre Boulez, who has been a regular guest conductor at the L.S.O. for more than 20 years. ''The musicians were very confident with him, because they knew he was a good man for ideas and intentions. Also, they were in safe hands for the money situation. They like to be adventurous, but at the same time, they like to be safe.'' Under Gillinson's leadership, the players have fought to establish the L.S.O. as the foremost British brand in classical music.
 On July 1, Gillinson, who is 59, will take over as executive and artistic director of an institution that carries the leading American brand name in classical music: Carnegie Hall. The match of the British orchestra manager and the New York concert hall makes immediate sense. In this country, Carnegie Hall is celebrated for its burnished sound and hallowed history, a combination that seems downright European; whereas in Britain, Gillinson's competitiveness and singlemindedness -- his ambition to leave his rivals shriveled and gasping in the dust -- often came off as aggressively American. ''When I first got to know him in 1985, Clive said, 'The U.K. needs one super-orchestra, and it's going to be the L.S.O.,''' says David Whelton, managing director of another prominent London orchestra, the Philharmonia. ''He's done a great deal, but if that was his objective, it hasn't been met.''
 In New York, Gillinson will find, along with a cultural climate that values victory over good sportsmanship, a brand of underdeveloped potential. Since it opened in 1891 with Tchaikovsky on the podium, Carnegie Hall has witnessed many great moments in American musical history. The premiere of Dvorak's ''New World'' symphony, the United States debut of the 16-year-old Jascha Heifetz and the return from retirement of Vladimir Horowitz are standouts. George Gershwin's ''An American in Paris'' made its debut at Carnegie Hall. Isadora Duncan, Ruth St. Denis and Martha Graham danced there. Judy Garland, Lenny Bruce, Frank Sinatra and Bob Dylan entertained there. Yet despite its venerable 114-year-old patina, Carnegie Hall is actually a young institution. In 1960, it narrowly escaped demolition, and it emerged from that near-death experience reborn. In its former life, it was a rental hall, a place for soloists or musical ensembles to hire out. On many nights it still fills that function, but since 1960 it has evolved from a landlord into a presenting institution, booking performers for a fee and then selling tickets to recoup costs. 
 The transition hasn't always been smooth. Until it completed a major renovation in 1986, Carnegie Hall, like the L.S.O. of that era, was worrying -- in its case, literally -- that the roof might fall in. When I asked Citigroup's chairman, Sanford Weill, the powerful head of the Carnegie board, if he had a vision for Carnegie Hall when he became a trustee in 1983, he said, ''I knew that it shouldn't be a place where the bathrooms leaked into the boxes.'' More recently, the growth of Carnegie Hall has been stunted by the deaths of its two most effective administrators. In 1998, Judith Arron died at 56 of breast cancer, after managing the hall for 12 years. Except for the violinist Isaac Stern, who led the fight to preserve Carnegie Hall and then served as president until his death in 2001, no one did more than Arron to forge the organization's modern path. By masterminding the creation of an intermediate-size basement space, Zankel Hall, which has 600 seats, she enabled Carnegie to present innovative artists who aren't mainstream enough to fill the 2,800-seat main auditorium (which is named for Stern).
 After a brief, bumpy interregnum, Arron was succeeded by Robert Harth, whose eclectic musical taste ensured that Zankel Hall would present jazz and contemporary and world music, as well as more traditional fare. Harth may be best remembered, however, for what did not happen on his watch. In the spring of 2003, Carnegie Hall and the New York Philharmonic announced a planned merger, which would have returned the orchestra to its former home. The philharmonic's elopement to Lincoln Center was what threatened Carnegie Hall's survival back in 1960. At that time, the City of New York came to the rescue, buying the building and leasing it to the nonprofit Carnegie Hall Corporation. More than four decades later, as the philharmonic faced a decision on renovating its aging and acoustically imperfect residence at Lincoln Center, both sides dreamed of erasing the past. As they negotiated, however, Harth and his board concluded that the abdication of the philharmonic, its linchpin tenant, had transformed Carnegie Hall so fundamentally that it made no sense to bring the orchestra back. Meanwhile, the New York Philharmonic was discovering that Carnegie's own programming and commitments would not allow the number of concerts and rehearsals the orchestra demanded. A few months after both sides abandoned the merger, Harth died of a heart attack. He was 47.
 As Harth's successor, Gillinson leads an institution that is pointed forward. Carnegie Hall has patched, scrubbed and expanded its interior. By closing the door on the philharmonic, it has reaffirmed its commitment to its own programs. In the music world, its board is unmatched for cash and clout, with trustees like Ronald O. Perelman, Jerry Speyer and Peter Jennings. Its endowment stands at $164 million or, if promised gifts are added in, at $210 million, which is about 25 times the L.S.O. endowment. At this point in its history, everyone can agree that Carnegie Hall is not just a building. But what is it? It comprises three halls -- Stern Auditorium, Zankel Hall and Weill Recital Hall -- which have distinctly different sizes but somewhat blurry individual presences. One-third of Carnegie Hall's endowment has been earmarked for education activities, which sometimes -- as with the popular, budget-priced Family Concerts -- are scheduled at the hall, but usually take place off-site in schools and community centers. However, what chiefly prevents Carnegie Hall from transmitting a clear identity is its split personality. Although no longer only a rental hall, it is still a rental hall. On a given weekend, the Berlin Philharmonic or the Chicago Symphony Orchestra might be playing in Stern Auditorium in a concert program presented by Carnegie. Just as plausibly, the hall could be hired out for a base fee of $12,250, more or less on a first-come-first-served basis, and the concert be given by the University Glee Club of Tokyo or the Grand Rapids Symphony. Two-thirds of the roughly 250 concerts in a season at Stern Auditorium are rentals. 
 Franz Xaver Ohnesorg, who ran Carnegie Hall in the interval between Arron and Harth, floated the idea of drastically reducing the number of rentals. The idea never took flight. ''I personally believe the rentals should not be thrown out,'' Klaus Jacobs, a longtime board member who became acting executive director after Harth's death, told me. ''They present concerts, orchestras, artists, which we would not present. I'm not saying it's a different tier.'' At this, he smiled: we both knew that the performers he spoke of belonged in a different tier, or even in a different arena altogether. He added, ''I think they have a certain right to present themselves in a city-owned institution.'' Ara Guzelimian, Carnegie's well-regarded artistic adviser, made a similar argument: ''It's a city-owned hall, and barring some extreme concern about the far edges of appropriateness, the hall is open and available for rental.'' Part of the hall's national reputation rests on the reports in local newspapers of the hometown orchestra or pianist achieving that pinnacle, a Carnegie Hall recital.
 Yet when I raised the question of whether there is too much rental programming with Gillinson, he allowed that it was something he had discussed with both Jacobs and Guzelimian. ''We've talked a lot about that,'' he said. ''Everyone there has a very strong feeling, which I understand and value, that one of the great strengths of Carnegie is, it belongs to the city. When other organizations want to present themselves there, to some extent this is a service that Carnegie gives to people who care about music. The other side is, you have less control over what is presented. On the face of it, I can see lots of strengths in the arrangement as it is. But like anything, you always have to keep challenging and testing yourself on your basic premises to see if they are really valid. I have no idea what the answer is, but the important thing is, you keep asking the questions.'' A handsome, articulate man with a ready grin and an affable manner, Gillinson displays the conservative plumage and speaks with the qualified equipoise of a politician or business executive. His corporate demeanor belies the quality that sets him apart in a typically standpat profession: his readiness, even eagerness, for change. 
In a highly atypical spell of ambivalence, Gillinson knew early on that he wanted to be a professional musician but studied mathematics instead. He attributes his reluctance to the influence of his Swiss-born mother, a cellist, who after World War II moved to India with his father, an officer in the British Army. Gillinson was born in Bangalore. Soon after, his father bought a 5,000-acre farm in the highlands of Kenya. By the time the Mau Mau uprising began, the marriage was already breaking up; his father stayed in Kenya, while the rest of the family left for England. There, Gillinson's mother tried to resuscitate her solo cello career, which had flourished before the war, but she banged up against many barriers as a female cellist, finding employment only sporadically on orchestral back benches. The experience embittered her and, for a while, discouraged Gillinson from following her lead. ''My mother was so adamant that I was seeing it through her eyes,'' he said. But after spending less than a year studying mathematics, he changed course and enrolled at the Royal Academy of Music, where he won the top cello prize and, upon leaving, secured a position in the cello section of the Philharmonia Orchestra. Strangely, it was where his mother worked, and they sat next to each other for three months, before Gillinson was offered an opening at the orchestra he yearned to join -- the L.S.O. He stayed for 35 years. 
 He intended to devote his professional life to playing the cello, until his flair for numbers and his air of competence led his colleagues to enlist him for a job that no one wanted. ''One of the things that suddenly hit me is the funny way fate works,'' he told me recently, over dinner at a Barbican Center restaurant. ''That morning, I went into the L.S.O. office because the orchestra was bankrupt, and I was going for three months while we looked for a new manager -- that irrational moment, which wasn't anything to do with my life, has turned out to lead to the job at Carnegie. Those little corners that you turn, that you don't realize at the time, can completely change your life.'' When Gillinson took control, the L.S.O.'s deficit stood at close to 15 percent of revenues. Within a few weeks of his arrival, the Arts Council informed him that unless that deficit was corrected within three years, the orchestra would lose its vital government subsidy -- an annual stipend, now about $3 million, that is matched by the municipal authorities of the City of London, where the Barbican is located. Eliminating the Arts Council money would have wiped out the L.S.O. Like a general, Gillinson roused the morale of the musicians for a long, slogging campaign, in which they chased after cheesy recording jobs and agreed to do one concert a year without pay. ''We cut holiday pay, we held our fees down,'' recalls Francis Saunders, a cellist. It was a punishing regimen, but it succeeded. Within two years, the L.S.O. had retired the deficit.
 Yet even while he was pursuing blatantly commercial work, Gillinson recognized that the L.S.O. had to take artistic risks to preserve its image and its soul. Apprehensively, he acceded to the insistence of Claudio Abbado, who was then the L.S.O.'s principal conductor, and went ahead in 1985 with an expensive festival of Mahler and fin-de-siecle Viennese music. By obtaining corporate sponsorship, which was still unusual in Britain, Gillinson financially floated the critically acclaimed festival. He followed it up with other costly but reputation-making events, like a 60th-birthday series for Mstislav Rostropovich in 1987. And no sooner had he stanched the L.S.O.'s financial hemorrhage than he was looking into the future.
 In 1987, Gillinson commissioned Saunders to initiate a six-month investigation of how the L.S.O. could further music education, which in Britain, as in the United States, has been increasingly neglected by the public schools. Rampant ignorance of symphonic music threatens orchestras directly. ''He had to talk to the players and get them to realize the way forward would have to include an educational dimension,'' Saunders says. ''Some of the players thought this was not the way we should be going.'' Raising pay scales for education work helped to sway minds. But what really won over most musicians was the education program's success, for which much of the credit goes to an astute hiring decision. Richard McNicol, a former schoolteacher and London Philharmonic Orchestra flutist, had been working since 1977 on finding hands-on ways for young people to experience music. (One technique was to have them compose their own music, using themes extracted from a piece they had never heard. They would then attend an orchestral performance of that piece and discover how the original composer had employed the same material.) In 1993, Gillinson offered McNicol a part-time engagement to develop concerts and other programs for children at the L.S.O. It was a new job category without even a name, so McNicol came up with ''animateur'' -- borrowed, he says, from a French term for ''someone who encourages people in activity in the arts or sports as a catalyst.'' Since then, virtually every symphony orchestra has established a participation-oriented musical-education department, many of them obviously inspired by the L.S.O. When Sir Simon Rattle arrived at the Berlin Philharmonic in 2002, he brought over McNicol to start an education program there. (After a year of commuting, McNicol relinquished the Berlin position, but the program he initiated continues.) At the Philadelphia Orchestra, its president, Joseph Kluger, says that he modeled his program directly on the L.S.O. template, down to the ''animateur'' name.
 More recently, many players grumbled when Gillinson's most audacious scheme -- the renovation of the derelict 18th-century St. Luke's church into an education center and rehearsal hall -- ran into construction difficulties, and the financial package he had painstakingly assembled from many sources, mainly national lottery funds and the banking giant U.B.S., no longer covered costs. To Gillinson's fury, the government balked at contributing much more, and so the players had little choice but to pitch in. Individually, they have forgone raises for two years. Collectively, the orchestra's endowment has suffered as fund-raising energy shifted to St. Luke's, and the L.S.O. ran up a deficit that reached $1.4 million last year. Fortunately, Gillinson eliminated the shortfall this spring. And notwithstanding all these problems, St. Luke's, inaugurated in March 2003, has been hailed as a colossal success, both as a technologically advanced education-and-rehearsal facility and as a very handsome architectural renovation. 
 Compared with managing the L.S.O., in which Gillinson seemed to pluck each string personally, running Carnegie Hall will be more of a conducting assignment: coaxing each section of the ensemble to play brilliantly and in balance. Although he will bear just as much responsibility for meeting a budget, Gillinson will not enjoy the same latitude in designing programs. Nor will he be able to exert artistic control as he did even in his final weeks in London, when he announced that Valery Gergiev, director of the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, would succeed Sir Colin Davis in 2007 as principal conductor of the L.S.O. However, Gillinson at Carnegie won't exactly be artistically powerless, either. For the concerts Carnegie presents, its administration negotiates programs with the orchestras it invites; if Gillinson has an overarching concept for a season, he can see it through.
 After the collapse of the merger with the New York Philharmonic, the Carnegie administration sought other ways to achieve continuity. An ambitious orchestra residency program, which Harth did not live to announce, will begin in the 2007-8 season with a visit of eight or nine days by the Berlin Philharmonic. Weill, the board's chairman, says that someday four orchestras may take up residencies, for a season total of four or five weeks. Carnegie Hall is now also spending close to $8 million a year on education. The magnitude of that sum probably attracted Gillinson to the job even more than his own salary increase: Harth was earning double the roughly $250,000 that the L.S.O. was paying Gillinson. Although he won't discuss it, Gillinson turned down an offer two years ago to be president of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The timing was wrong -- his two youngest children were still at university -- and the position would have amounted to a more fettered version of his existing job. He says that he wanted the Carnegie Hall position as soon as it was offered to him last July, and that when he held a retreat with his wife, Penny, and their three grown children, his major worry was that his family might disagree. They unanimously endorsed the move.
In both the United States and Britain, classical music is confronted by long-range challenges that will not solve themselves. Recording contracts for orchestras have dried up. Audiences resist what is loosely called contemporary music (although some of it was written almost a century ago). The days when a couple would routinely buy a full-season subscription seem as quaint and remote as a cotillion ball. Although statistics are scarce, audiences in concert halls seem to be growing grayer. To cover rising costs, tickets keep becoming more expensive. In short, classical music is jeopardized and marginalized, and there's no easy fix. 
 At the L.S.O., Gillinson developed the approach to these problems that he will take to Carnegie Hall. For instance, he foresaw long ago that the symphonic recording business, following an upswing propelled by the new CD format as listeners replaced their vinyl albums with discs, would languish. Aside from the lost income to the players, this was an orchestra problem. Without recordings, how could the L.S.O. preserve performances with great conductors and soloists, and how could it expand its reputation and keep the pool of people who attended its concerts from stagnating? ''For about two years, from about 1996 on, I started talking to the orchestra at every meeting about what was happening in the recording industry,'' he said. ''It was hardly happening yet, but it was clear to me that they couldn't keep rerecording the symphonic repertoire. I deliberately made sure it was a conversation, and then the orchestra saw it happening. I said: 'What should we do about it? There is no money from the recording companies to make CD's, so if we want to record them, we will have to do it ourselves. The only way we can do it is if we share the risk. We will take the risk of financing the recordings, but you will have to take the risk of postponing the payment, and then, if the royalties come in, you will get most of them.''' 
 The upshot was ''L.S.O. Live,'' begun in 2000, a groundbreaking series of live recordings that includes a Grammy Award-winning performance of the Berlioz opera ''Les Troyens'' conducted by Colin Davis. Record companies have always released live performances, and on their in-house labels orchestras have issued historic recordings exhumed from their archives, but the self-produced L.S.O. series, designed as an orchestra-controlled alternative to a studio recording system, offers another business model. The label, which is nicknamed ''L.S.O. Clive'' by the musicians, now offers 32 discs. Its success has been influential. As part of a Mahler series, the San Francisco Symphony released its first new recording under its own label in 2002, and last year, the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra in Amsterdam inaugurated its own label as well. One decision that divided even the L.S.O.'s administrators was how to price ''L.S.O. Live.'' Here, too, Gillinson defied conventional thinking. ''It was one of the very rare occasions when I and the marketing department couldn't come to a consensus,'' he recalled. ''I was absolutely adamant that it had to be budget-priced and accessible to everyone. They were convinced that that would undermine the brand. I finally said, 'I'm very sorry, but I have to insist.''' He issued the ''L.S.O. Live'' discs at slightly under $10, or about half the cost of a premium CD in Britain. ''They now think it is the right decision, because we have sold so many,'' he said. Most ''L.S.O. Live'' titles sell 25,000 copies in the first year of release; with that volume, the slim profit margin is financially defensible. Moreover, as a megaphone to amplify the L.S.O.'s reputation, the series has succeeded brilliantly. And a number of recordings have won prestigious prizes, underscoring the democratic thrust of the pricing. ''I was absolutely certain in looking at the marketplace, where there are endless recording companies and recordings, there is no way the pressure won't be to bring the prices down,'' Gillinson said. ''It is much better to dictate to the market than to be dictated to.'' (Continuing to look ahead, the L.S.O. made its entire catalog available for download online on iTunes in April.)
Gillinson encountered similar resistance when he proposed reducing ticket prices for concerts at the Barbican. ''I'd been pushing for it for years,'' Gillinson told me. ''Each time the marketing department was adamantly opposed.'' For the centennial season of 2004-5, wanting the buzz of full houses, the L.S.O. made the leap and cut the cost of the top ticket from $66 to $47, with similar reductions down the line. Other orchestra administrators questioned its sanity. ''Why price a Rolls-Royce product on a Ford Mondeo level?'' argues David Whelton of the Philharmonia. ''One of our roles is to see that the brand is respected and exploited.'' Even Sir John Tusa, managing director of the Barbican Center, advised Gillinson that there was no advantage in reducing prices for patrons who could afford expensive tickets. But Gillinson said he thought that he needed to act boldly to change public perceptions. If only the lower-priced tickets were reduced, ''people will still look at the pricing from the top and think it's 35 pounds downward,'' he explained. ''You have to build up the audience.'' To cover the potential shortfall in ticket revenues, Gillinson reduced the marketing budget by some $190,000. So far, the policy has not conspicuously increased demand, but Gillinson says he hopes that, if maintained, it eventually will. 
 If younger and more diverse audiences are to be enticed into concert halls, the music itself, not just the ticket prices, must appear approachable. In recent years, the L.S.O. has backed away from contemporary music. Defending his predictable programs, Gillinson blames a conservative mood that has seized audiences since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. ''Everybody got spooked and stopped going out,'' he said. ''It was very marked and very noticeable that autumn. People then started coming back, but they were much more selective, and they wanted to be sure they would enjoy the program.'' In the 2002-3 season, the L.S.O. presented a series devoted to the lyrical, rigorous music of the young English-born, French-trained composer George Benjamin. ''Five years earlier, that would have succeeded,'' he told me. ''I shouldn't say it was unsuccessful. It did very well critically. But in 2003, the attendances were 65 to 70 percent on average. That's a big, big drop. Either you say, 'I'm just going to go on, regardless,' or you say, 'We can't afford to.' You take a step back and make sure you've got your audience with you. There's no point in doing things that are interesting and challenging if people aren't going to hear it. It's a waste of time.''
 Even in relatively sanguine days, Gillinson strove to transform unusual programs into events. He staged a Shostakovich festival, in which Rostropovich conducted all 15 symphonies and some seldom-heard works, to full houses. An educator as well as a showman, he supported McNicol, the animateur, in the creation of the L.S.O. Discovery series, which uses the orchestra to illuminate the obscurities of modern music. In January, on a Carnegie Hall visit in honor of Boulez's 80th birthday, the L.S.O. performed a Discovery concert devoted to Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.'' Before the intermission, Boulez and his interlocutor, Guzelimian (filling the role McNicol had taken in previous European performances), used the orchestra to demonstrate how Stravinsky constructed the work in rhythmic chunks. Then the orchestra returned to perform the piece uninterrupted. Remarkably effective, it was the first event in what Carnegie has dubbed its Sound Insights series. As Guzelimian told the audience, ''This is, if truth be known, directly modeled on the Discovery concerts that the London Symphony Orchestra has been doing for 15 years.'' Before Gillinson's arrival, Carnegie Hall had already put in place a program that flattered him by copying him. 
 Unlike the L.S.O., Carnegie Hall has managed to press ahead with unusual programming even after Sept. 11. Next season, as part of a boundary-pushing series he designed, the conductor David Robertson, who is the new music director of the St. Louis Symphony, will perform a program of Luciano Berio, Gyorgy Ligeti and none other than George Benjamin (admittedly, in Zankel Hall). Demonstrating Carnegie's scope, the Senegalese singer Youssou N'Dour will also program a series.
 The stately dignity that Carnegie Hall embodies can be off-putting to new audiences. Although Zankel Hall seems to be drawing a younger, hipper crowd than the one that usually comes to Stern Auditorium, Gillinson recognizes the continuing challenge. ''Wonderful, extraordinary cultural palaces can be intimidating for people who have never experienced great music before and think that culture is for other people,'' he said. Sometimes even small things can be significant. The Carnegie Hall logo, unchanged since 1983, represents the name of the institution in a capitalized old-fashioned typeface, with a red bar below it. At the L.S.O., Gillinson commissioned a new logo, in which the three letters swoop in a ribbonlike arabesque. ''In the end, what we said was, 'Hang on, we see ourselves as vivid, exciting and energetic, and here we have a logo which has nothing to do with how we see ourselves,''' he explained. So he got one that did.
 Unlike his mercurial predecessor Ohnesorg, Gillinson knows that to institute change in a venerable institution, patience and clarity are required. ''If you try to sell too many ideas at one time, you can find you don't get any of them through,'' he remarked. In addition to considering a reduction in the number of rentals, Ohnesorg also proposed taking over the adjoining Carnegie Hall Tower studios, which Carnegie now leases out, and other expensive, ambitious schemes. He accomplished little except for antagonizing his colleagues. Gillinson has been seasoned by working for a self-governing orchestra that requires near consensus, in a British system that imposes thickets of bureaucracy and protocol. Reviewing his own record in London, he seems at once proud and frustrated. Earlier this year, he waged a frontal assault of lobbying for more financing for the L.S.O. from the Arts Council, which five years ago changed its policy and began distributing public money equally to the nation's orchestras. His campaign failed. The L.S.O.'s outsize ambitions would have to wait. ''Why bother to have an arts council?'' Gillinson complained to me. ''For our orchestra, it's shattering. For years they were thinking they were being rewarded for what they achieved.'' Gillinson may be better suited to working in New York than in London. ''In Britain, people are concerned that everyone be fair and no one be upset,'' he said. ''I've always felt really at home in the States. People love to applaud success and don't find it threatening. People are inspired by it. It's one of the things that I've found hardest with being in Britain. People are quite comfortable with failure, but they are much less comfortable with success. That's one thing I won't be sorry about leaving behind.''

SECTION: Section 14; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk; THE NEW BROOKLYNS/SIGNS OF CHANGING TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2105 words

HEADLINE: The Great Awakening

BYLINE: By SUKETU MEHTA. 
Suketu Mehta is the author of ''Maximum City: Bombay Lost and Found'' (Knopf).

 BODY:
AT a party on the Upper West Side in 2000, a distinguished American author, and longtime Manhattanite, asked where I lived.
 ''Brooklyn,'' I told him.
He snorted. ''Poor people live in Brooklyn.'' Then he turned away to get some meat.
 Shortly after the party, to see if I could move from my rented apartment in Boerum Hill, I went looking to see what I could buy in a part of Fort Greene where cars parked on the street were still regularly stolen. I told the broker that it would be nice for my kids to have a house by a park. ''We just sold a house by the park: $510,000,'' the broker said. But there was a catch. ''It had no walls or ceilings.'' 
 What happened, I wondered, to the distinguished author's ''poor people''? 
 Several years ago before, representatives of the giant warehouse shopping club Costco had approached the City Planning Department with a question: would it be worth it to open a Costco in Sunset Park, an area of Brooklyn that had lots of the aforementioned poor people? The economic data wasn't encouraging. Lots of Asian immigrants lived in the area, and their median income was not high. Also, the site was half the usual size, so the Costco store would have to be built in two stories, with costly elevators and escalators. 
 But the city's statisticians advised Costco to go ahead. There was money in those undistinguished apartment houses and wood-frame houses, they said, more money than met the eye. Being an immigrant area, the neighborhood has a thriving underground economy, they said, and official housing data doesn't account for illegally subdivided units. 
 The store opened in 1996 and turned a profit in its first year. Nine years later, according to company figures, it is among the nation's highest-grossing Costcos, earning upward of $150 million this year compared with $120 million for an average Costco. In fact, the store has been so successful, the chain is considering opening another giant warehouse in Brooklyn.
 It has become a cliche to say that Brooklyn is booming. But the change has become so broad -- sweeping up the yuppies of Fort Greene, the immigrant shoppers at Costco, the hipsters of Williamsburg -- that it looks for all the world like a difference not just in degree but in kind. Long seen by that distinguished author and by so many others as a poor backwater, Brooklyn now buzzes with a momentum that would have stunned residents of its sleepy streets not long ago. The change has effects salutary (a housing boom, thriving cultural life) and perilous (soaring housing costs, displacement), but the one constant is that it is huge. 
 With 2.5 million people, the borough is bigger than San Francisco, Boston, Atlanta and St. Louis combined. The population is approaching the historic high of 1950, when Brooklyn was home to 2.74 million souls. Turn around, and you will see the renaissance. There isn't a single vacant storefront along Fulton Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and hordes of shoppers throng Pitkin Avenue in Brownsville. After decades of disinvestment in Brooklyn, major projects are in the works, among them the development of 175 waterfront blocks, complete with 40-story luxury apartment buildings, along the Greenpoint-Williamsburg waterfront; the construction of an 800,000-square-foot sports complex for the Nets in the Atlantic Yards; and, in Red Hook, the return of cruise ships, including the Queen Mary 2 and the Queen Elizabeth 2, to a major new pier and passenger terminal. 
 And while housing is exploding citywide -- the number of housing permits granted citywide last year exceeded the permits granted in all of the 1990's -- the two boroughs with the most housing starts in this bustling market are Queens and Brooklyn. Why so many homes? Brooklyn's prime appeal is relatively low cost. Let's not kid ourselves. If rents in Manhattan fell, half the hipsters in Brooklyn would rush the bridges; they're a floating population. But it can't be just that; otherwise Staten Island and the Bronx would also qualify. 
 People are also moving to Brooklyn because -- who in the 80's could ever have guessed? -- it has become so much safer. From 1990 to 2000, according to the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services, car theft in the borough plunged by 75 percent, robbery by 67 percent and homicide by 69 percent. In terms of mass transit, it's the best-connected borough after Manhattan, with 167 of the city's 468 subway stations. 
 AS for me, I live in Park Slope because I'm a writer. It's in my union contract. Brooklyn has become the Iowa City of the East, an area chronicled and cataloged and celebrated in countless novels and poems, read and unread. The number of Brooklynites who identified themselves as ''authors and writers'' to the Census Bureau more than doubled to 3,111 in 2000 from 1,506 in 1990. By contrast, the number of ''cabinetmakers and bench carpenters'' dipped almost by half over the same period, to 334 from 602. 
 Because of all the creative types who call the borough home, the new Brooklyn is hip. One of the clearest signs of this was a 2002 cover article in Time Out New York that ran under the headline ''Manhattan -- The New Brooklyn'' and tried hard to make the case that Manhattan was cool again. ''The Upper East Side is just a dorm,'' I overheard a young Asian hipster say to a friend as they walked amid the milling crowds on Court Street. ''I like it here. There's so much life.''
 Sometimes all of South Brooklyn feels like a giant set for a sitcom about trendy young people. On plywood barriers at a construction site on Fourth Avenue in Park Slope, I noticed a series of desperate public pleas for a change of heart by a departing roommate: ''I 3/5sheart 4/5 You Scout Please Don't Leave''; ''Scout if you stay I'll be nice to you all the time. Even when I'm PMS'ing''; ''Kate says if you stay, you can spend another night in her bed.'' 
 It was not always thus. The unnamed young Irish hero of the Gilbert Sorrentino love story ''The Moon in Its Flight,'' set in 1948, returns to Brooklyn after a party with his sophisticated Bronx girlfriend in equally sophisticated Forest Hills. At the party, ''He skulked in his loud Brooklyn clothes,'' the novelist writes.
 ''When he got off the train in Brooklyn an hour later, he saw his friends through the window of the all-night diner, pouring coffee into the great pit of their beer drunks. He despised them as he despised himself and the neighborhood. He fought against the thought of her so that he would not have to place her subtle finesse in these streets of vulgar hells, benedictions, and incense.''
 But the new Brooklyn has more than one face. ''There are two Brooklyns,'' pointed out Arun Peter Lobo, deputy director of the population division of City Planning. ''At the very least.'' Indeed, anything you could say about Brooklyn, the fourth-largest city in America, is true somewhere within its borders. Yes, it's full of hipsters; Rhode Island School of Design students hop on the bus to Williamsburg as soon as they graduate. Yes, it's full of parents, marching their strollers down Union Street to shop at the organic foods co-op. Yes, it's also full of immigrants. 
 Although Queens, the borough most thought of as the new melting pot, is home to more than a million immigrants, Brooklyn is fast catching up, with 932,000. About 38 percent of Brooklynites are foreign-born; if you include their children, their numbers jump to more than 55 percent. 
 This isn't the Jewish Brooklyn of Woody Allen or the Italian Brooklyn of ''Moonstruck.'' There are people living in Brooklyn who have no idea what stickball is, what stoop-sitting is, who the Dodgers were or why they left Brooklyn. These people play cricket in Marine Park, barbecue suckling pigs in their backyards, listen to Russian matinee idols in Brighton Beach nightclubs, and worship not Kobe Bryant and Derek Jeter but Diego Maradona, an Argentine soccer player, and Sachin Tendulkar, an Indian cricket star. They are inventing their own Brooklyn, a Brooklyn their kids will be nostalgic about 20 years from now. 
 Willy Loman, too, still lives in Brooklyn. Desperate working folks, salesmen and otherwise, struggle to provide for their families, to make the commission; attention is still not being paid. Income disparities are as big as Brooklyn itself; in 2000, the median household income in the wealthiest census tract -- in Brooklyn Heights -- was $112,414. In the poorest tract, in Coney Island, the median income, at $7,863, was not even one-tenth of that. The housing crisis exacerbates this inequality, with the world divided between those who own and those who rent. 
 Another big division in Brooklyn is between neighborhoods close to the water, or to a park, and those away from the blue and the green. People live in the western parts of Brooklyn with their eyes fixed westward. There are people in Park Slope who can tell you where to get the best gelato in Manhattan but have no idea where to find the best roti in Brownsville. Well inland are the nonimmigrant poor, people who have been poor for a long time and aren't just off the plane from somewhere else, aren't hoarding hope for their children as they toil in sweatshops.
 The new Brooklyn has not cured poverty or solved related problems like inadequate schools. Low-quality schooling hits poor and immigrant families the most because it depletes the only substantial capital they have: their children. The children, with their great promise, are these families' Microsoft before Windows, their I.B.M. when it was just a typewriter company. When a public school succeeds spectacularly, like P.S. 321, in whose Park Slope district house buyers must pay a premium, parents storm the gates, with varying success. So it's private school for many Brooklyn parents -- at $20,000 a year. ''It's become punitive living here,'' says a writer friend who was trying to raise her kids in Park Slope. She couldn't afford a house, even though her husband is a corporate lawyer. Eventually she left Brooklyn to ride horses in a mountain village in Spain, and is happier for it. 
 MOREOVER, the various redevelopment plans, grand as they are, are being fought block by block by people who will be displaced by them. The Nets arena will sit in a spot that has among the best access to mass transit in the city -- ''every train but the F,'' as my landlord proudly said when I was renting an apartment near there in 2002. Traffic, already hellish on Flatbush Avenue, may get still more hellish as several thousand fans converge at game time.
 So there are downsides to the new Brooklyn, but there is the boom -- and beyond all the economic data, there is a very human pull to the borough. In the world's loneliest city, Brooklyn offers community. Everybody can find community in Brooklyn: the body-fluid artists in Bushwick, the Chinese restaurant workers in Sunset Park, the die-hard Marxists in the Park Slope food co-op. No matter how foreign or fringe you are, the borough has a support group for you. 
 One reason for this is that Brooklyn is famously a series of neighborhoods. Another has to do with the physical structure of that emblem of Brooklyn -- the brownstone. Adjoining rear gardens facilitate communal interaction, gardening tips exchanged over a backyard fence. Maybe what attracts the hipsters to Brooklyn isn't just cheap rents. It's the closest they can get to the families they left behind, in Kansas, in Vermont, in Tokyo.
 For me, Brooklyn became a neighborhood one steamy August night in 2003. It was the night of the great Northeastern Blackout. In Park Slope, volunteers were out directing traffic at every intersection, even if the drivers laughed at them and zoomed past. Other Brooklynites shared phones and flashlights, or helped the elderly down dark stairwells. 
 As night fell, the texture of the city changed. The street lamps were out, and people strolled about with flashlights and lanterns. There was a bright white moon high above the city competing with the red glory of Mars, the warrior planet, which hadn't been so close to Earth in 60,000 years. The ancient Brooklyn tradition of stoop-sitting enjoyed a sudden revival.
 At midnight, the bars were still dispensing ice for our whiskeys. We took our drinks out on the sidewalk; we'd make our own laws tonight. Everyone's face was illuminated in flickering, flattering light, and everybody looked beautiful and desirable. The floodlit megalopolis was transformed into a series of villages lighted by millions of small lights, in whose glow Brooklyn was revealed to be what we had forgotten it really is: an impossibly romantic, a 19th-century city.

HEADLINE: Market's Surge Erases Losses for the Year

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
The stock market surged last week, wiping out its losses for the year, despite an increase in the price of oil.
 Consumer confidence in June jumped from the previous month, according to a report on Friday by the University of Michigan, contributing to the stock market rally. 
Crude oil futures in New York reached a new high of $58.60 during the day on Friday. That set off a climb in energy shares, which accounted for a significant part of the stock market's overall gains. 
 The market shrugged off a government report showing that the current account deficit for the first quarter reached $195.1 billion, more than expected by Wall Street economists.
 The best performers among the Dow industrials included Alcoa, Honeywell and Exxon Mobil. 
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 110.44 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 10,623.07. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.85 points, or 1.6 percent, to close at 1,216.96. The Nasdaq composite index rose 27.11 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 2,090.11. 
 The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.07 percent from 4.05 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

BYLINE: By Joseph P. Fried

 BODY:

2nd Round of Charges Against Doctor's Killer
 He is serving 25 years to life for a highly publicized killing, but James C. Kopp may face life without parole if federal prosecutors have their way.
 In October 1998, Dr. Barnett A. Slepian was killed by a rifle bullet fired through the kitchen window of his home in Amherst, N.Y., a Buffalo suburb. Dr. Slepian, who was 52, had an obstetrics practice in Amherst and performed abortions at a clinic in Buffalo.
 Investigators quickly focused on Mr. Kopp, above, a longtime abortion opponent with ties to extreme anti-abortion groups. An international manhunt for him ended with his arrest in France in March 2001.
 In a nonjury trial on state murder charges in 2003, Mr. Kopp admitted that he had shot Dr. Slepian, but claimed he had meant only to wound him so that he could not perform more abortions. 
 But the judge, Michael L. D'Amico of Erie County Court, found that Mr. Kopp had intended to kill Dr. Slepian and was guilty of second-degree murder. Judge D'Amico sentenced him to the maximum, 25 years to life in prison. Mr. Kopp, 50, is appealing the verdict and sentence, under which he is eligible for parole after 25 years.
 Now, federal prosecutors in Buffalo are pressing their charges against Mr. Kopp, among them a charge that he violated a federal statute barring forceful interference with people who provide reproductive health services. If a death resulted from such interference, a conviction could lead to life in prison without the possibility of parole.
 In April, Magistrate Judge Hugh B. Scott of the Federal District Court in Buffalo recommended that Mr. Kopp's motion to dismiss the charges be denied. The magistrate rejected, among other things, the argument that the federal prosecution violated strictures against double jeopardy. The federal trial judge, Richard J. Arcara, can accept or reject the recommendation.
 Last week, Mr. Kopp's lawyer, John Humann, maintained that the federal prosecution was ''a waste of time,'' given the state conviction. 
 ''He's doing 25 to life, and even if he's alive after 25 years, the parole board would not release him,'' he said. He said he also thought that his client had ''no chance'' of successfully appealing the state conviction.
 Dr. Slepian's widow, Lynne Slepian, declined to comment. But her lawyer, Glenn E. Murray, who was Dr. Slepian's lawyer and friend, said that Ms. Slepian ''would like to be able to tell'' her four sons, now 14 to 22, ''that Mr. Kopp will spend the rest of his life in jail.'' 
 She can not say that with certainty under the state sentence because of the possibility of parole, he said, but ''she can say it if he's successfully prosecuted'' and gets life without parole in the federal case.
 Beyond that, said the prosecutor in the federal case, Kathleen M. Mehltretter, it is important to enforce the law safeguarding health providers.

4 Years Later, Steps Toward Science Park
 For years, critics said that city and state officials had not done enough to spur the growth of biotechnology and life-science industries in New York City. 
 The city responded in part by approving plans in 2001 for an East River Science Park, three buildings to rise on city-owned land between East 28th and 29th Streets off Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan. The complex, to be located between New York University Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital Center, would house companies involved in the research and development of products like pharmaceuticals and medical devices.
 Such projects move slowly, but last week aides to Andrew M. Alper, above, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the agency hoped to select a developer by the end of the summer from among five who recently submitted proposals for building the complex.
 William R. Fair, a corporation vice president, declined to disclose the contenders but said the one chosen would finance the ''vast, vast portion'' of the expected cost of several hundred million dollars.
