HEADLINE: Missing Links

BYLINE: By RICHARD KORMAN

 BODY:
ONCE, when the suburbs were new and booming, gasoline retailers had to update their handout maps of Long Island almost yearly. Each new edition bore more dashed lines for highways under construction and dotted ones for proposed routes, promising more convenient travel all over an island where traffic was building as fast as the tract housing.
 Now an era is ending. The widening of the Long Island Expressway to add high-occupancy-vehicle lanes, which should be completed the first week of July, is likely to be the last major addition to the Island's network of expressways and highways. Experts agree that it is now all but impossible to build new trunk roads, at least in Nassau and western Suffolk and probably on the whole island. Neither the land nor the money nor the political will exists to do it.
So, while there are still plans to upgrade some roads, the highway network the Island has now is essentially the one it will have to live with. 
 And judging both by today's traffic jams and by the dotted lines on yesterday's maps, that network is missing some significant links.
 Thanks in part to Robert Moses, the planner who starved mass transit for decades to lace the region with bridges, expressways and winding, scenic parkways, Long Island life today cannot help but revolve around the automobile. From 1973 to 2003, the number of registered vehicles on the Island grew three times as fast as the population, according to the Regional Plan Association.
 But the business of building roads has become much harder since Moses' time. Rights of way have disappeared, environmental reviews have become more far-reaching, community activism has grown more potent, and land values have skyrocketed.
 Now, even to talk about a new exit ramp in many neighborhoods is to know how an I.R.S. agent feels walking up to a ranch in North Dakota. State highway officials, whose 720 miles of roads on Long Island carry nearly half its traffic, are now cautious and consensus-minded, a far cry from the push-it-through, come-what-may style of the Moses years.
 As a result, the pace of improvements to the road network lags far behind the need, according to Lee Koppelman, director of the Center for Regional Policy Studies at Stony Brook University. Anything that is done now, he said, ''is strictly Band-Aids.''
 Looking back, the missed road-building opportunities are legion: ghost interchanges never set in concrete, bridges that died on paper and highways that failed to rumble from imagination to reality.
 To be sure, some of the projects would probably have been magnificent disasters. In the 1960's, for the sake of adding links to the web of roads serving the whole Northeast megalopolis, Moses and like-minded planners considered extending the expressway system deep into both forks, encircling the harbors and bays of the North Shore with a belt of steel highway bridges, and even flinging a span from Orient Point to Rhode Island. The damage done to some of Long Island's most scenic and historic communities would have been incalculable.
 Even the more reasonable of the unbuilt projects, though, would have shaped a different Long Island, experts and historians say, by pushing development into still-fallow corners, splitting neighborhoods, displacing families and businesses and changing property values. 
 On the other hand, one expert suggests that limited-access highways might actually have reduced sprawl in some towns, the way a rail line can, by concentrating development near the access points.
 With the road-building era ending, most of the public emphasis today is on mass transit improvements for commuters, like a new Long Island Rail Road link to the East Side of Manhattan and more express-bus service, perhaps using lanes reserved for buses.
 But some experts question the wisdom of the new emphasis. Since much of the driving Long Islanders do is unrelated to commuting, ''how wise is public policy that makes people miserable in their cars?'' said Frank Braconi, an economist who splits his time between homes in New York City and Suffolk County. ''That can only discourage spending and make people consider living in Asheville, N.C.''
 There are other reasons, besides a maddeningly slow commute, to regret some of the gaps in the Island's highway network. They force cars and trucks onto local streets, setting the stage for more accidents. Towns respond by posting more stoplights and stop signs, slowing travel further. Shipping costs rise for the vast majority of goods, which travel by truck. And the added wear on local streets pushes up taxes.
 Here are some of the notable highway projects that got away.

Double-Decking the L.I.E.
Proposed -- 1963.
Purpose -- Adding through lanes for Island-to-city traffic.
Problem -- Aesthetics.
Fate -- Dropped within a few years.
 The Long Island Expressway was far from finished, but it was already well on its way to infamy. Commuters clogged the western section with 130,000 trips a day through Queens, according to nycroads.com, a Web site that collects historical information about the region's highways. 
 The New York City transportation commissioner at the time was Henry Barnes, the engineer who came up with the timing of green lights on major avenues to speed traffic flow, among other innovations. 
 In 1963, Mr. Barnes had an idea for expanding the expressway's capacity in Queens: three more lanes in each direction, plus a four-lane second deck above, supported on huge T-shaped concrete pillars. 
 The upper deck would have been an express causeway with no exits or entrances from the Nassau line to the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in Maspeth. All four lanes would have run inbound in the morning and outbound in the evening. 
 But the road would have been a hulking intrusion through the Queens neighborhoods it traversed but did not serve, a weakness that Mr. Barnes himself acknowledged.

Next Exit, New England
Proposed -- Around 1968.
Purpose -- A sound crossing that avoids the city.
Problem -- Opposition from coastal communities on both ends.
Fate -- Allowed to languish.
 To link Long Island to the mainland with a path of steel and concrete over Long Island Sound has been a dream of many planners and officials. Robert Moses wanted a bridge between Bayville and Rye, N.Y., in part to speed truck traffic on the East Coast. An engineer who studied the proposal in 1968 breezily concluded that such a bridge would quickly pay for itself. 
 Construction was begun on Route 135 to feed the bridge, but residents of Oyster Bay and Bayville dug in to fight it. Despite the economic benefits and convenience for drivers, the bridge would have blighted ''one of the few areas left that still look like they did 100 years ago,'' said Geri Solomon, assistant dean for special collections at Hofstra University.
 Meanwhile, competing proposals divided bridge supporters. A state study group recommended a 10-mile causeway from Rocky Point to Old Saybrook, Conn.; a plan for a 24.6-mile chain of bridges linking Orient Point and Napatree, R.I., would have cost twice as much. 
 Planners still talk about a Sound crossing, but give it little emphasis today. In a study of Long Island's needs after 2000, the state Department of Transportation said a Sound crossing would have been a wash, in terms of relieving congestion. 

A New ExpresswayFor the North Shore
Proposed -- 1970.
Purpose -- Relieve congestion on the L. I. E., remove through traffic from local roads.
Problems -- Cost, local opposition.
Fate -- Allowed to languish for years, eventually abandoned.
 Rona Wafajow of Huntington enjoys driving the curving tree-shaded stretches of Route 25A near her home -- until she finds herself stuck behind a five-ton truck. 
 An expressway to sweep the trucks and commuters off North Shore secondary roads would have made sense, Ms. Wafajow said. As it is now, Route 25A is often jammed, and ''everybody wants to jump ahead of one another,'' she said, especially where the road narrows to a single lane each way.
 East-west secondary roads like Route 25A, Jericho Turnpike, Old Country Road and Pulaski Road bear unusual burdens on Long Island, as many drivers try to avoid choked expressways and parkways. In 1970, the Nassau-Suffolk Regional Planning Board estimated that 15 more lanes of east-west highway were needed. It recommended a new 40-mile expressway to be built somewhere between the Northern State Parkway and the Sound. 
 The precise right of way was never spelled out, but it probably would have replaced at least some stretches of Northern Boulevard, and would have required condemnation of some very expensive real estate. 
 A preview of the likely community reaction came in 1957, when the state proposed realigning Northern Boulevard in Manhasset to bypass a steep curving hill -- and half of the Miracle Mile shopping strip. After fierce opposition peaked at a long, raucous public hearing at Manhasset High School that was interrupted by a bomb scare, that plan was shelved.

A New ExpresswayFor the South Shore
Proposed -- 1936 and later.
Purpose -- Relieve or replace Sunrise Highway in Nassau.
Problem -- Community disruption.
Fate -- Abandoned in 1966.
 Access to Nassau County's South Shore is one of the major deficiencies of Long Island's highway network, with the only choices the cars-only Southern State Parkway and the endless traffic lights of Sunrise Highway. ''The whole southern half of the Island is underserved,'' said Mark Kulewicz, director of traffic engineering and safety for the Automobile Club of New York.
 In the 1960's, the Tri-State Transportation Commission laid out a plan for an Atlantic Expressway in Nassau, in place of Sunrise Highway or parallel to it. From the Queens line to Wantagh, the highway was pictured as an elevated eight-lane roadway on columns or earth fill, according to nycroads.com. From there east to Amityville, it would narrow to four lanes and be below grade, with service roads on each side. 
 Steve Anderson, the former Long Island resident who created nycroads.com, said building it would have been hard even then. But had it been built, he said, an Atlantic Expressway would greatly help move traffic through the area, just as the expressway-grade stretch of Sunrise Highway has in Suffolk. 
 But now, even a modest upgrade along the Nassau portion is out of the question, Mr. Kulewicz said, because the business corridor that has grown up around Sunrise Highway is too important to demolish. ''If you could have seen 50 years into the future to build it, then maybe,'' he said.

Cedarhurst to Roslyn In Less Than an Hour
Proposed -- 1952.
Purpose -- Creating a north-south through road in western Nassau.
Problems -- Cost, community disruption.
Fate -- Abandoned in the 1970's.
 Lee Koppelman of Stony Brook University calls it a textbook example of bad planning. On many days, a driver can go from Suffolk County all the way to Manhattan faster than from Great Neck to Woodmere, a distance of just 18 miles, because western Nassau, one of the most densely developed areas of Long Island, has no north-south expressway or parkway of its own. 
 ''Further east you have the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway and the Wantagh and Sagtikos State Parkways,'' said Sheila Pantuliano, a Baldwin resident, ''but there's nothing in western Nassau except the Meadowbrook, which is always backed up.'' 
 Not that people haven't tried to build one. As far back as early 1952, the state pushed a plan for a six-lane expressway from Atlantic Avenue in Freeport to Northern Boulevard in Roslyn. But hundreds of homes and businesses would have been displaced. Opponents won an agreement to extend the Meadowbrook State Parkway north instead; it linked with the Northern State Parkway in 1957.
 State officials tried again in 1963, with a route that was to start at Sunrise Highway in Valley Stream, and snake northward along the Long Island Rail Road West Hempstead branch and some disused tracks in Hempstead and Garden City, finally curving northwest to Middle Neck Road in Port Washington, according to nycroads.com. But problems with the right of way made it unfeasible. 

A Parkway Past Stony Brook
Proposed -- 1960's and 1970's.
Purpose -- Extend the Northern State to north-central Suffolk.
Problems -- Rapid development, environmental issues.
Fate -- Shelved repeatedly.
 When Smithtown and northern Brookhaven began to develop rapidly in the 1960's, it was obvious to planners that a road would be needed from Hauppauge to Port Jefferson Station, through what was largely empty land in those days. To serve the area, Robert Moses proposed extending the Northern State Parkway along a right of way that Suffolk County already owned. 
 But it never happened, and Route 347 was built instead. Now, with that road choked with traffic and development and the state planning costly and excruciating upgrades for it, the failure to extend the parkway looks like a costly error to some. 
 ''Had the road been maintained as a limited-access highway as originally envisioned, perhaps we would have fewer of the local traffic issues,'' said John Kennedy, a Suffolk legislator from Hauppauge. ''It would have obviated the gridlock,'' he added.
 Michael and Mary Mart of Port Jefferson, who have operated a bookstore in the village since 1972, said that in hindsight a parkway would have been a better choice than Route 347, which they now try to avoid. 
 ''It would have made sense if we knew what the population was going to be now,'' Mr. Mart said. ''But then, Port Jefferson was considered extremely out of the way. It was considered the end of the world then.''
 The state last studied extending the parkway in the 1970's, and found that rapidly rising land costs, environmental problems and community opposition would make it impossible. Later plans to upgrade Route 347 to an expressway have also foundered. 

Easing the Squeeze On the South Fork
Proposed -- Early 1980's.
Purpose -- Relieve the bottleneck near the Shinnecock Canal.
Problem -- Environmental issues.
Fate -- Shelved in 1984.
 Hardly anyone who lives in or visits the East End wants an expressway barging through it. But though travel times there have become a maddening guessing game, urgent road upgrades remain years away. Motorists can only sit and suffer, and wish the work had started long ago.
 State officials were ready in 1969 to extend Sunrise Highway 23 miles from Shinnecock Hills along Peconic Bay to Amagansett, but local opposition was stiff. 
 ''The money was appropriated, and D.O.T. was summarily left at the altar,'' said Ann LaWall, a Southampton traffic commissioner and executive director of the Southampton Business Alliance. ''That route would have traveled over very sensitive terrain. I wasn't for it then, and I'm not for it now.'' 
 In the late 1970's, Suffolk County offered an alternative, widening and upgrading 11 miles of County Road 39 in Southampton. It, too, met intense opposition. ''They didn't want it then, but they want it all now,'' said William Hillman, Suffolk County's chief highway engineer. 
 Now that the situation has reached what Ms. LaWall called a crisis stage, the county has revived the proposal, but Mr. Hillman said work could not begin until 2008 at the soonest -- and then only if federal financing becomes available.

HEADLINE: Former Executive Chosen to Lead N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By ANNE BERRYMAN

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 25 

 BODY:
The N.A.A.C.P., departing from a custom of looking to political or religious figures to lead the organization, named a former business executive, Bruce S. Gordon, as its president and chief executive on Saturday.
 Meeting in private, about 60 members of the organization's board voted unanimously to choose Mr. Gordon, 59, who retired in 2003 as president of the retail markets group for Verizon Communications. Mr. Gordon will now negotiate a contract with the N.A.A.C.P.'s executive committee; if they reach a deal, the board will formally vote on Mr. Gordon's appointment at its convention next month in Milwaukee. 
 A force in the 1960's civil rights movement and still a leading voice for African-Americans, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has recently faced criticism for its lack of membership growth. The current membership is about 500,000, said John White, a spokesman for the group. 
 The group has also faced financial woes, accusations of misconduct by its former president, and an Internal Revenue Service inquiry into its tax-exempt status prompted by criticism of the Bush administration last year by Julian Bond, the N.A.A.C.P. chairman. Tax-exempt organizations are supposed to be nonpartisan; Mr. Bond has said he was objecting to policies, not a party, and he continues to speak against goals of the Bush administration, including private accounts within Social Security, and what he calls ''tax giveaways to the rich.'' 
 In a news conference Saturday after the vote, Mr. Gordon said, ''The N.A.A.C.P. should have a relationship with whoever is in the White House, regardless of whether he was put there by a blue state or a red state.''
 ''I hope we can find some ways to work together,'' he said of President Bush.
 If approved, Mr. Gordon would succeed Kweisi Mfume, who resigned in December, initially citing his desire for a vacation and to spend more time with his youngest son. But more recently, Mr. Mfume, just after announcing his intentions to run for a Senate seat from Maryland, was accused of giving raises and promotions to women at the N.A.A.C.P. with whom he had had relationships. He denied the accusations.
 Mr. Gordon was born in Camden, N.J., where his father founded a chapter of the association. By age 8 he was attending N.A.A.C.P. meetings with his parents, both teachers. He earned a bachelor's degree from Gettysburg College and a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 He began working at Bell of Pennsylvania as a management trainee in 1968 and spent 35 years in the telecommunications industry.
 He serves on the Executive Leadership Council, a national organization of black executives that trains high school and college students for corporate careers. Mr. Gordon and his wife, Tawana, live in New York City, and they have a 27-year-old son.
 Sensitive to the N.A.A.C.P.'s recent difficulties, Mr. Gordon spoke of cohesiveness in the organization several times during the news conference. He promised that the group ''will function in a united, consistent, respectful way.''
 Mr. Gordon spoke of trying to increase membership, work with other organizations, create an endowment and get the organization, which ran a deficit last year, on strong financial footing.
 Mr. Gordon said he would like the N.A.A.C.P. to address economic issues like the unemployment rate among African-American men; access to health care benefits; opportunities for black-owned companies to manage large pension funds; and representation for African-Americans in all levels of employment in corporations. 
 He said his own ''bias'' was that ''economic power and economic equality enables social justice.''
 ''The facts are as clear as can be that people of color are treated by a different standard,'' Mr. Gordon said. He said his goal was to ''change the deficit that exists between our community and the community at large.'' 
 When asked afterward whether that represented a decreased emphasis on politics, Mr. Gordon said, ''I'm going where the trouble is.'' 
 At the start of his news conference, he said, ''This day will stand out in my life as no other,'' adding, ''My biggest hope is that many days from now this day will stand out in the history of the N.A.A.C.P.''

HEADLINE: Sharing Housing Costs And Herb Gardens In Oregon's Largest City 

BYLINE: By LINDA BAKER

DATELINE: Portland, Ore. 

 BODY:
SHELLEY FLYNN, a program director for Volunteers of America, had considered buying the two-bedroom house she had been renting in the southeast part of the city, but she worried about stretching her budget to pay the $200,000 mortgage.
 So last summer, Ms. Flynn, who is 32, bought a $246,000 bungalow in the same neighborhood with her friend Janet Bartholomew, a sales manager at the Bullseye Glass Company, a glass manufacturer for artists and architects. Ms. Bartholomew's boyfriend, Woody Sleeper, shares the house with the two women as a renter. 
 ''I realized that economically it would have been really challenging for me to buy a house alone, and even if I did do it alone I still would have had to take on roommates,'' said Ms. Flynn, who moved to Portland six years ago from Boston. ''So why not look at doing it with friends, where there's at least a better chance of having a living situation that works?'' 
 As housing prices in Portland enter a second year of double-digit appreciation, a growing number of first-time home buyers are seeking entry into the market by purchasing houses with friends. Although no exact figures are available, local realtors, mortgage brokers and other housing experts say co-ownership arrangements are springing up with increasing frequency. 
 ''The cost of the market has gotten so high that many people are priced out if they buy alone,'' said Michelle Puggarana, a trainer with the Portland Housing Center, a nonprofit group that connects buyers to housing options. At least two people in each of her biweekly workshops expresses interest in some kind of joint tenancy with friends, Ms. Puggarana said. ''The reality is that we will see more and more of these types of purchases.'' 
 In the metropolitan Portland area, the median home price was $230,000 in May, 12.7 percent higher than the price in the comparable month in 2004, $204,000. 
 The trend toward co-ownership is also fueled by the city's high proportion of young adults, many of whom express interest in pursuing alternative, community-oriented lifestyles. 
 According to a recent study of migration by 25- to 34-year-olds, the Portland area ranks eighth in attracting that group -- the top three cities are Las Vegas, Austin, Tex., and Phoenix -- and it is fourth in attracting people in that age group with college degrees. The report -- published in 2004 and sponsored by the Portland Development Commission and the Westside Economic Alliance, an economic development association -- says young adults like the city's distinctive neighborhoods, public transportation, bike friendliness and environmental ethic, as well as its open-minded, tolerant attitudes. 
 Ms. Bartholomew, who rented an apartment with Mr. Sleeper before buying her current home with Ms. Flynn, said she prefers communal houses. ''In a romantic situation, you act as a unit,'' Ms. Bartholomew said. ''When you're living with friends, you're more of an individual. It feels healthy, fresh.'' 
 Eli Spevak, 34, who develops affordable housing, and his friend Jim Labbe, 33, an urban conservationist with the Audubon Society of Portland, also fit the progressive Portland demographic. In 2003, the two men converted a run-down seven-unit apartment complex, Peninsula Park Commons, into an affordable condominium community for their friends and acquaintances, including one couple with a 15-month-old child. 
 Mr. Spevak and Mr. Labbe sold the 630-square-foot one-bedroom units for around $90,000 each; the 720-square-foot two-bedrooms went for about $112,000. Mr. Spevak plans to build several three-bedroom units in a lot next to the existing complex, which is in a gentrifying neighborhood several miles northeast of downtown Portland.
 Profit was not a motivator, he said. ''We wanted to live among friends and informally share things like a canoe and lawnmower,'' he said. 
 Peninsula Park Commons is fronted by a landscaped courtyard featuring native plants, a vegetable garden and patio furniture where residents can gather to share evening meals. 
 A communal unit, which Mr. Labbe and Mr. Spevak set aside as a shared space for all residents, includes high-speed computer access, a discreetly covered television and a bedroom for out-of-town guests. Earlier in the week, Mr. Spevak said, residents held a T-shirt-making party in the common room to prepare for Pedalpalooza, an annual citywide bicycle celebration.
 Mr. Spevak and Mr. Labbe formed a limited liability corporation, Peninsula Park Commons, to buy and operate the complex, then converted the building into condominium units, which they sold to themselves and their friends.
 In most cases when friends share a house, they follow standard home loan and payment procedures. ''It's one of those places where lenders just don't care,'' said Julee Felsman, a senior loan consultant with Equity Home Mortgage in Portland. ''They throw the income into one pot.''
 Ms. Felsman, though, did advise prospective buyers to talk to a lawyer and think about an exit strategy. ''One party might get on someone's nerves or get married,'' she said. 
 Ms. Flynn and Ms. Bartholomew, who had discussed several ''what if'' scenarios but never put anything in writing, said the household weathered its first crisis a few weeks ago when Ms. Flynn broke with the threesome's vegetarian philosophy. ''Shelley left a greasy chicken pan in the sink,'' Ms. Bartholomew said. ''It was a blowout ordeal.'' 
 Portland residents who have remained in joint households for several years have benefited from the region's strong price appreciation. In 1999, Saima Gillette, a special-education teacher, bought a three-bedroom, $140,000 house in North Portland -- about a mile south of Peninsula Park Commons -- with her married friends Tom and Shelley Butler. ''I wanted to live in a community, and it seemed like a good way to invest money,'' said Ms. Gillette, who had contributed $3,000 as a down payment. 
 When Ms. Gillette decided to move out last summer, the house had almost doubled in value. Her friends bought her out for $30,000. 
 ''Tom and Shelley had a baby last summer, and I said, 'O.K., I'm not into that,''' said Ms. Gillette, who now lives alone in a rented studio loft. ''Things have their season.''

HEADLINE: Welcome to Asbury Park, a Work in Progress

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK 

 BODY:
IT is a breezy, sunny Thursday -- full of promise, it would seem, for the summer ahead. Yet in downtown Asbury Park, the streets are empty, eerily so. This compact seaside city -- founded with a somewhat religious fervor in the late 1800's -- has experienced many revivals in the century or so since then.
 Bettye Atkins is a believer.
 ''It's exciting and I feel it coming,'' said Ms. Atkins, who for the past eight years has owned Footsteps in Paradise, a shoe store downtown. ''I am one of the pioneers and I am looking forward to the new faces.'' 
 Eight years can seem like forever, but Ms. Atkins said she is not worried if she has to wait a little bit more. ''Some people say the time is now, but I say it will take 5 or 10 years. Still, you keep a positive spiritual attitude and it will come around.''
 The next couple of years will be crucial for this city of almost 17,000, which watched its fortunes plummet in the latter part of the 20th century, and for a time the city struggled to reinvent itself as it shrugged off shaky developers and shady elected officials. 
 Until now, redevelopment has been scattered and slow, and a stroll through this faded resort can still be a grim experience. Several years ago, gays -- who had grown tired of the scene, the schlep and the soaring prices of the Hamptons and Fire Island -- were attracted to Asbury Park by the affordable housing and beautiful if tattered architecture. And these days million-dollar condominiums are selling briskly and a milelong swath of the boardwalk has been repaired. 
 The next hurdle is simply whether enough people will buy into something that is at once a dream and a memory. 
 The statistics can push the story either way. On the plus side, the big numbers seem to be 44 and $1.1 million, as in 44 of 48 condominiums ranging in price from the mid-$400,000's to $1.1 million already sold in the new eight-story Barcelona -- a three-building beachfront condominium complex that is expected to be completed next year.
 Yet there are other daunting numbers. There is the poverty rate: 36.1 percent of the city's residents live below the poverty level -- the highest rate of any city in New Jersey except for Camden. And there are 20.5 violent crimes per 1,000 citizens, double the rate of any other municipality in Monmouth County. 
 Nor does it stop there. The unemployment rate in Asbury Park is 12 percent, more than three times the state average. There are 100 women for every 88 men; 30 percent of the population is younger than 18 and more than 40 percent of the children live in poverty. In 2002, only 25 percent of the city's high school graduates went on to college, and 51 percent of the middle school students had either been suspended at one time or expelled completely.
 For a city investing so heavily on its future, Larry Fishman, chief operating officer of Asbury Partners -- the lead developer for the city's waterfront properties -- is unusually blunt. Earlier this year, he said that he would still recommend that families with children not buy in Asbury Park because of its troubled school system.
 ''In some ways, I regret that statement because it came off so negative,'' Mr. Fishman said. ''But you have to understand that there is still a way to go in Asbury Park and buyers of expensive properties might not want to use a school system that will eventually improve.
 ''The city was hit particularly hard by the urban unrest of late 1970's and early 1980's. A large part of the tax base disappeared and there was a general disregard for the important qualities the city had, either by the former municipal governments or people who might have been potential investors for the city.''
 Still, Asbury Partners -- a private developer -- has glorious plans. There are 3,000 new housing units envisioned over the next 10 years, 525 of which should be finished by the end of next year, he said. In addition, there are also plans for nearly a half-million square feet of commercial and retail space along the oceanfront, and a similar amount among scattered developers downtown.

Not There Yet
 But the city is not there yet. Construction cranes dot the oceanfront and some buildings downtown show signs of renovation -- a piece of latticework scaffolding here, a Dumpster there, newly polished windows or pointed bricks on a building or two.
 Steven Troy owns one of those buildings, where he and his partner, Robert Legere -- both in life and in business -- have owned Robert Legere Home, a home-furnishings and interior-design company for almost three years, what Mr. Troy describes as an eternity here.
 ''I think we are going to be the first business to record a year with $1 million in sales in downtown Asbury Park in a long, long time,'' said Mr. Troy, who admitted that most of the firm's business was not derived from customers who walked in off the street. 
 On the other hand, he said that he and Mr. Legere had renovated the apartments above their business and recently sold one to a married couple, both doctors.
 ''It's just the type of sale the city is looking for,'' said Mr. Troy, who was recently appointed to the Asbury Park planning board. ''It's exciting. We just have to reach critical mass and things will snowball.''
 For a long time, the snowball had been rolling the other way -- eventually reaching an avalanche of bad news. Asbury Park's precipitous slide -- depending on whom you ask -- began in the late 1940's, the mid-50's, or the late 60's. 
 The reasons offered for Asbury Park's disintegration are many -- from the emergence of suburban living after World War II to construction of the Garden State Parkway to better airline travel to the city's racial upheaval to shopping malls to Great Adventure to the release of mental patients to ethically-challenged developers and city officials. There is even an excuse that Asbury Park was too fancy to keep up.
 ''Asbury Park had these magnificent structures, some built as early as the turn of the 20th century,'' said the city's historian, Werner Baumgartner. ''As the tourist trade started to decline in the 1960's and 1970's, and you were left with a large hotel, what could you do? The state started to mainstream people with controllable mental disorders and Asbury had these big places to accommodate them. It just furthered the city's growing bad rap. Its elegance pushed its demise.''
 Yet it was the buzz of nostalgia -- along with skyrocketing real estate prices up and down the New Jersey coast -- that kept Asbury Park going. 
 ''Homes that no one wanted five years ago, that may have gone for $150,000, are double and sometimes triple that now,'' said Gwen Pastorelli of the Mary Holder Agency in nearby Sea Girt. ''And people, in lots of cases New Yorkers, are buying them expecting the same thing to happen in the next five years.''
 Ms. Pastorelli, who went to kindergarten in Asbury Park, said that while local residents may still be somewhat skeptical of the boom here, New Yorkers -- particularly artists fleeing Greenwich Village and Brooklyn -- are enthusiastic.
 ''When artists come -- and Asbury is getting more and more a reputation of being an artsy community -- it's a win,'' she said. ''It gives the community a positive image.''
 Years before the artists arrived, there were great efforts on the part of Bruce Springsteen and his musical heirs, yet the city's boardwalk amusements declined to nearly nothing. While neighboring towns like Ocean Grove and Loch Arbor thrived, and other communities not too far away -- Rumson, Deal and Spring Lake -- went over the top in prestige and price, Asbury was mired in despair.

Developers Look to Future
 These days, developers are no longer disturbed by old news. Metro Homes, one of the subdevelopers with Asbury Partners, has done much of its work in Hoboken, another New Jersey city that was down on its luck and is now thriving.
 ''It is an energy you feel right now,'' said Paul Fried, a general partner of Metro Homes, which is building the Esperanza, a 224-unit condominium complex a block from the ocean. 
 There will be two towers of 16 and 10 stories, and a design that Mr. Fried said is the architect's interpretation of wind and waves. 
 ''This is a place people have long looked to for fun, and we want to do as much as we can to bring it back,'' he said. ''It is true that it is a long way back, a lot of it in memories, but the time seems to finally be right.''
 The city manager, Terence J. Reidy, who generally speaks for the city on development issues, said things are happening in Asbury Park now because of stability in city government and, to be sure, the lack of other places along the New Jersey Shore that have land to develop.
 ''The mayor and the current council came in after a long time of failed development and municipal corruption,'' said Mr. Reidy, referring to the 2003 conviction of former Mayor Kenneth E. Saunders and the indictment of several of his aides and political associates for fraud and tax evasion related to development. ''They went about this latest round of redevelopment methodically with competent developers. I won't say there won't ever be another mistake or slip-up, but there are checks in place, and things seem to finally be going well.''
 In part, Asbury Park may have an easier time in terms of redevelopment than, say, Atlantic City because of the compactness of the city; the 2000 census showed 16,930 residents in a city of only about 1.5 square miles.
 ''You can compare it, I guess, with Atlantic City, which was bigger and really bad,'' said James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. ''There may not be as much to overcome. Plus, there is a real boom going on in oceanfront property. Asbury Park has a lot of it, and they aren't making any more.''
 So while the lack of schools and services may deter families from settling in Asbury Park in the near future, Mr. Hughes said, that should not keep away the panoply of empty nesters, from retirees to young singles to the gay community. 
 Mr. Troy was looking for just such a place after he retired early from his advertising career.
 ''I had lived for 27 years in California before I came to New York,'' he said. ''Then I spent two summers in Provincetown and two on Fire Island. Every time I bid for a place in Fire Island, boom, I'd get outbid right away.''
 He read about the possibility of Asbury Park becoming a gay enclave, and he ventured down in April 2000.
 ''I was shocked by what I saw,'' he said. ''These grand homes on the North End with such great potential. We were able to buy one without a problem.''
 Mr. Troy and Mr. Legere, who left a successful fashion design business, saw in the aftermath of Sept. 11 a need among people to get out of the major cities, yet stay nearby. They started their home-furnishings and interior-design business and became active in city planning and other organizations.
 ''I really believe that this will be the next great city of the sea,'' Mr. Troy said. ''I believe it more than I did the day I came here five years ago.''
 But not quite yet. Those condominiums on the waterfront -- even those 44 already sold -- have not yet been built, and the first is not expected to be finished before the end of 2006. The smattering of new restaurants that have opened are generally not open early in the week but fill up quickly on the weekends. 
 For now, people are renting summer homes and apartments in neighboring Ocean Grove. The Stone Pony, the premier rock club, is on Preservation New Jersey's list of endangered places, and the crime and poverty rates in the residential areas have not changed appreciably in years.
 But as long as there are people like Mr. Troy and Mr. Fishman making investments and Ms. Atkins willing to wait, the revival of Asbury Park may not be so bizarre a dream. After all, its was belief that gave birth to Asbury Park in the first place.

Founded as a Christian Resort
 It was founded as a Christian resort by a New York brush manufacturer and real estate speculator, James A. Bradley, who named it after Francis Asbury, a circuit-riding preacher who was the first Methodist bishop in the United States. The town grew considerably in the 1880's and 90's, particularly after an outbreak of diphtheria in Long Branch in 1887.
 ''I came here from Fair Haven, which is a pretty affluent town, because I had a girlfriend on her deathbed who saw me opening a shoe store and being successful,'' Ms. Atkins said. ''I don't know, this was her dream, so it became my goal. I didn't know anything about the retail business. I was a social worker.
 ''But here I am eight years later and I have customers from everywhere and I'm hanging in there,'' said Ms. Atkins, who has also done social work and run food concessions on the boardwalk to make ends meet.
 ''Now maybe the redevelopment will take off and I'll be ready,'' she said. ''I'm not afraid if it doesn't again this time, though. I'm happy to be here and I'm ready to stick it out longer.''

HEADLINE: Some Summer Moments to Remember (or Perhaps Forget)

BYLINE: By Neil Genzlinger

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY'S summer officially began on Tuesday, causing we at the Jersey Column to wonder: What would a collage of the Garden State's most memorable summer moments look like? We didn't know, so we sought input from an assortment of history buffs, longtime residents and ordinary smart alecks. We asked them to pick a pivotal moment from summers of yore, one that they would have liked to experience or, if they were there for the original, would like to experience again. 
 The results were nothing if not eclectic -- kind of like New Jersey summers themselves:

MONMOUTH COUNTY, 1778: Late June, of course, brought the Battle of Monmouth. Richard Veit, a professor at Monmouth University who wrote ''Digging New Jersey's Past,'' would like to have seen it (''from a distance,'' he notes), partly to compare how archaeological efforts at the battlefield match up with how things actually unfolded, but partly for a somewhat less scholarly reason.
 ''George Washington is reputed to have used foul language with General Lee at the battle,'' he said. ''Historians have long debated what was said, by whom and in what tone. I would love to know. Was Lee called a damned poltroon, or something stronger?'' 

HADDONFIELD, 1858: Hoag Levins, editor of HistoricCamdenCounty.com, wishes he had accompanied a visiting Philadelphian named William Foulke to one particular dinner in Haddonfield that summer. The dinner's host told Foulke, an amateur fossil collector, of some curiously large bones seen in a marl pit.
 ''That conversation,'' Mr. Levins said in an e-mail message, ''led to the digging that by fall had unearthed Hadrosaurus foulkii, the fossil skeleton that gave science its first look at the full and quite peculiar anatomy of a dinosaur.'' 

OCEAN CITY, 1880: Paul S. Anselm, president of the Ocean City Historical Museum, wishes he could travel back 125 years to see for himself the summer when a famed resort was basically created from scratch on a slip of land now known as Ocean City.
 ''Seven and a half miles long, nothing but grass and dunes: that's what it was when they started,'' Mr. Anselm said. The founders, he said, ''were good Christian men, but they knew their business'' -- if they wanted the crowds to come, they realized, they had to have something for them to come to.
 ''That first year must have been unbelievably busy,'' he said. If he is preoccupied with 1880, it's understandable: a recent museum renovation turned up a previously unknown diary written by one founder, S. Wesley Lake, during the period.

OVER THE DELAWARE, 1926: Sandy Levins, program director at the Camden County Historical Society (and wife of the aforementioned Mr. Levins), would have liked to be among the thousands who turned out on the first day of July to tread on the region's newest marvel: the Delaware River Bridge, since renamed for Benjamin Franklin. People were invited to walk across the span before it was opened to traffic, and the experience was as scary as it was amazing.
 ''Fashionable ladies, accompanied by men in straw boaters, shuddered as they looked down at the river 135 feet below them, and then up at the bridge's massive steel towers,'' Ms. Levins said. 
 The region's economics were in for some shuddering as well, she said: the bridge put river ferries out of business, opened South Jersey to development and let Philadelphians more easily escape the city to head ''down the shore.''

ASBURY PARK, 1963: The place, says Helen-Chantal Pike, who wrote ''Asbury Park's Glory Days: The Story of an American Resort,'' was the Panorama Room of the local Howard Johnson. The occasion, that June, was the quaffing of the first alcohol on the boardwalk since the ''dry'' resort was founded in 1871.
 ''I was in the single digits then, so my HoJo elbow-bending was connected to a coffee ice-cream soda,'' she said, but what made the moment possible was a liquor license that was restricted to the restaurant's second floor. 

LONG BRANCH, 1881: Though it's out of chronological sequence, the suggestion from Andy Breckman of Summit, creator of the USA Network's nutty detective show ''Monk,'' has been saved for last because of its sheer audacity. In July 1881 a gunman shot President James A. Garfield in Washington; later he was brought to Long Branch in the futile hope that the sea air would help him recover. Why would Mr. Breckman have liked to be on hand when Garfield succumbed on Sept. 19?
 ''I'd always have the best story at any dinner party,'' he said, adding with his tongue buried in cheek, ''but I'm sure that's what everybody's going to say.''

HEADLINE: Revenge Of the Sniff

BYLINE: By TAMMY LA GORCE

 BODY:
FIRST, a couple of questions:
 Is it appropriate to tell a man that his fly is open? Answer: Yes, according to most manners experts.
Is it O.K. to pick your teeth with a business card that has just been handed to you? Answer: If you have to ask, you may as well crumple up this newspaper, toss it to the floor of your train and go back to bellowing into your cellphone.
 Yes, manners are back. And the etiquette business is booming in, of all places, New Jersey. Unlikely as it seems, corporations both in and out of the state are turning to a new generation of proper New Jerseyans for guidance on exceedingly good behavior. 
 In the last five years alone nearly a dozen businesses specializing in excellent posture and using the right fork -- from Cape May to Chatham -- have shepherded tens of thousands of trainees into straightening up and flying right. And they are persuading limp handshakers, clumsy small-talkers and all kinds of boarish boors nationwide to be next in line for class at an increasing clip.
 (Purists, of course, will sniff that the Garden State's penchant for good manners truly started with Millicent Fenwick, the iconoclastic congresswoman from Bernardsville who, as an associate editor at Vogue in the 1940's, wrote the pleasingly rigid ''Vogue's Book of Etiquette.'')
 Nonresidents -- having seen way too many episodes of ''The Sopranos'' -- might snicker, ascribing about as much faith in a New Jersey-led surge in manners awareness as a Texas-rooted trend toward daintiness, but Jonathan Reader, a sociology professor at Drew University in Madison, says the trend actually makes sense. 
 ''More white-collar people are coming to New Jersey,'' he said, ''and they're looking for comparable positions in management. They want to know what etiquette is.'' 
 More important, he added, ''is that any edge in the marketplace counts these days. That New Jersey would be a place companies outside the state would look for etiquette training isn't surprising. There are a lot of corporations here, and more and more that are turning to suburbia. In turn, New Jersey has influence.'' 
 And with New York City across the Hudson and the state's own swollen population, he said, ''people here need to know how to be forcefully polite.'' Or just plain polite. 
 ''I can't believe people don't know this, but you're not supposed to clip your fingernails or floss your teeth in front of other people,'' said Corby O'Connor, who runs Corby O'Connor and Company, a business etiquette and protocol training firm in Essex Fells. ''Employers are dismayed with the level of sophistication of their employees, and a lot of times they should be. It's dreadful. Kids show up for interviews wearing flip-flops and holding Starbucks cups. There are no standards.'' 
 What there is, says Ms. O'Connor -- who started her company in 1999 and who says she has conducted programs on dining etiquette, image and ''meeting and cubicle etiquette'' for employees at Merck, Prudential, Merrill Lynch and other major corporations in New Jersey and New York -- is hope.
 ''A lot of times people are really receptive to what we have to say. There's plenty of interest -- the business has been growing every year since I started it -- and it's all from word of mouth and referrals,'' she says. ''In a word, what we're offering is confidence. People want to be socially aware. They want to walk into a room and feel at ease.'' 
 The need for manners makeovers knows no geographic boundaries. Students in South Carolina are just as apt to flunk Barbara Pachter's etiquette awareness quiz as they are near Pachter and Associates' Cherry Hill headquarters, said Ms. Pachter, who travels for nearly half of the 100 seminars she holds annually. The demand for such training, propelled in New Jersey by Izod-clad country clubbers and shlubs alike, she says, squares with the economic reasons cited by Professor Reader.
 ''We're in an up cycle now,'' said Ms. Pachter, who co-wrote ''The Complete Business Etiquette Handbook'' (Prentice Hall), and has followed it with others, including ''The Jerk With the Cell Phone: A Survival Guide for the Rest of Us'' (Marlowe). ''In New Jersey we have a lot of pharmaceutical companies and a lot of financial companies, and the economy has gotten more competitive. I did a workshop at a major financial consulting company recently where the director lost a $30 million deal because he offended the client by licking his knife. When an incident like that happens, all of a sudden it's 'Uh-oh, we better do something.'''
 More broadly, manners mavens say, the rush to civility was brought on by a generation coming to terms with its somewhat slovenly upbringing. 
 ''People in business now never had a dress code when they were growing up, and schools got so fearful of litigation for a while that nobody wanted to be the one to say, 'You can't come to my class looking like that,''' said Maureen Sanders, president of High Road Solutions in Martinsville. ''Now young employees are kind of clueless. They aren't catching on, and they don't want to look like a lout. I'm always surprised at how eager kids are to learn.'' 
 For Ms. Sanders, who says her business has grown 100 percent since it started in 2000, ''kids'' can mean college students -- for several years she has conducted an annual ''quick and dirty'' on dining etiquette and presentation skills at Rutgers, Kean and Seton Hall -- or young professionals in accounting firms or insurance companies or, even, actual children. 
 But the real challenge is the adult who acts like a child. After watching executives pick inappropriate protuberances, a woman saunter barefoot into a corporate training session and more than their share of business diners sipping from -- oh, the utter shame -- the wrong glass of water, Ms. Sanders, Ms. Pachter and Ms. O'Connor would probably agree. So would Ann Nicol, of Nicol Associates in Glen Ridge, who regularly rails against casual Fridays at some of the state's most prominent law firms, which she declined to name. 
 ''Clothes are an issue, and people get very confused,'' she said. ''You have to explain that you can't wear flip-flops or dress like you're going to a garden party. People are starting to realize it's vital that they learn what's correct to be successful.'' 
 There are those, of course, who never forgot. And perhaps the real trick when it comes to etiquette, if you don't want an account executive to amuse clients by burping the company's name, is to snag future leaders when they're children.
 Lois Thomson, president of the Barclay School in Westfield, makes a practice of preserving propriety's old ways, right down to the starched party dresses and crystal punch bowls. ''We've been around for 75 years -- we started in Summit -- and we've always accepted children to our program by invitation only,'' said Ms. Thomson, who now operates her school in 17 communities across New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Connecticut. ''Children in third grade up through sixth and seventh learn for whom to stand, how to seat a partner, how to share a plate of cookies or a bowl of chips.'' 
 And they do it while wearing jackets and ties or white gloves and Mary Janes.
 For some children, this has resulted in ''wet pants and throwing up,'' she conceded, but evidence of its appeal has been renewed lately. ''Our enrollment has gone up in the last few years, and naturally we can't take everybody. But parents who were raised in the 70's under the 'live and let live' idea are anxious for their childrento have a little more control. People want this.''

HEADLINE: An Overhaul of the Horse Racing Industry in New York Is Recommended in a Study

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE

 BODY:
New York's three major thoroughbred racetracks should be run as a business for profit in partnership with the state, all off-track betting outlets should be folded into the enterprise, and video lottery terminals should be allowed at Belmont Park, according to a study by an independent advocacy group to be released tomorrow.
 The group, Friends of New York Racing, said that by replacing the New York Racing Association with such a model, the state would attract capital investment of $500 million to $1 billion. It would produce more than $6 billion for education in its first 10 years and, by increasing current purses and breeder awards by more than 60 percent, assure the state's horse racing future, according to an executive summary of the report, which was obtained by The New York Times.
 ''No serious analyst would suggest if the policymakers and the industry were starting fresh, that New York horse racing and wagering would be organized as it is today,'' said the report, written by Tim Smith, the president and chief executive of the Friends of New York Racing. ''Based on the current circumstances -- fiscal, political, legal and otherwise -- there is perhaps the best chance in several decades to create a new and better model.'' 
 The New York Racing Association's franchise to run Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga Race Course expires after 2007, and on Friday the State Legislature established an oversight board that could take over the operations of the tracks if NYRA does not overcome its legal problems. Federal monitors have overseen its operations as part of a plea agreement for its role in a 2003 tax-evasion scandal involving several mutuel clerks.
 As early as August perhaps, they will issue a report to the United States Attorney's office on whether or not the association has carried out anti-corruption measures and good business practices. If so, the charges will be dropped against the association, which has paid a $3 million fine.
 Gov. George E. Pataki will appoint a nine-member ad hoc committee perhaps as early as July to come up with a process to put the racetracks up for bid. With 4,500 video lottery terminals to be in place at Aqueduct by next summer, New York's racing franchise is expected to attract numerous bids from well-heeled racetrack operators, casino companies, private equity firms and perhaps even technology companies. NYRA handles more than $2.7 billion in horse racing bets annually.
 In fact, the board of Friends of New York Racing includes some possible bidders for the association franchise, including the racetrack operators Churchill Downs Inc. and Magna Entertainment Corporation.
 But the two proposed business models in the study also reflect the goals of New York horse owners and breeders on the board who want to maintain a racing product that is considered second to none in the nation and that has an economic impact of $1.3 billion to the state, provides 16,900 jobs and encompasses more than 152,000 people, including owners, service providers, employees and volunteers.
 The first recommended model is a public-private partnership in which the state and participating local governments own 40 percent of the tracks and receive upfront fees totaling an estimated $150 million for the racing franchise and off-track betting jurisdictions and an equity ownership estimated to generate $695 million from 2007 to 2012. In the privatization model, the state would receive nearly $500 million up front, but no continuing ownership.
 The report notes that ''the creation of the New York City OTB in 1970 was perhaps the single biggest blow to NYRA's original business model, since it effectively eliminated a large percentage of NYRA's customers and revenues.'' It details the ''persistent insolvency'' of the racing association for the past 35 years, culling from audit reports by the state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and a criminal investigation by state Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who concluded in a 2003 report, ''The current structure has not, does not and will not work.''
 With NYRA losing $10 million annually and the Off-Track Betting Corporation's fighting to stay afloat, the study recommends consolidating operations. 
 By installing an additional 5,000 video lottery terminals at Belmont Park, a mammoth and underused facility accessible from New York City and Long Island, the franchise would be attractive to outside investors.
 ''The current structures for horse racing and off-track wagering in New York are 50 and 30 years old, respectively,'' the report said. ''Today, there is broad agreement among policymakers, industry leaders, academics and others that the current NYRA and OTB business models are 'broken' in numerous ways and should be replaced.''

HEADLINE: Jeb Bush, a Fan of Surrealism

BYLINE: By DOMINIC PATTEN

 BODY:

In the land of the hurricane, the higher and more inland museum is king. The Salvador Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., home of the largest collection of Dali's work outside Spain -- and a place where visitors can buy flip-flops and lip balm bearing his visage -- wants a new building to battle the triple threat of too many storms, not enough space and not enough money. Recently, its hopes seemed as forlorn as the downcast face in ''The Average Bureaucrat,'' one of the paintings in its collection: Florida newspapers reported that Gov. Jeb Bush would veto relocation funds because he thought them an inappropriate use of the state's Conservation and Recreational Land Fund.

But late last month, Mr. Bush and the mayor of St. Petersburg, Rick Baker, reached a deal. The governor would let the $4 million allocation stand, and the city would spend $2 million to turn a parking lot across the street from the new museum site into a waterfront park. The museum also promised to match the state's contribution through local fund-raising; Mr. Baker said that close to $3.3 million had already been pledged.

The city's efforts on behalf of Dali, the Surrealist master, who died in 1989, are firmly based in reality. In 2004 the museum attracted more than 220,000 visitors (just 30,000 fewer than the city's population), who contributed an estimated $65 million to the local economy. In that year, Florida was hit with four hurricanes, which all posed a serious risk to St. Petersburg. Hank Hine, the museum's director, said the Dali had to move its collection of 100 paintings and more than 1,000 other works into storage twice because of the threat of flooding. The museum wants to move from its one-story structure on the waterfront, left, to a new three-story building downtown that would double its floor space to 20,000 square feet and, Mr. Hine said, ''get the collection up higher, away from any flooding.'' He estimated the total cost of the move at $25 million, some of which would come from the sale of the present building. Jacob DiPietre, Governor Bush's spokesman, said last week that Mr. Bush believed the Dali was ''an important museum, a great place to visit, and after the city made their own funding commitment, he felt releasing the funds was the right thing to do.'' DOMINIC PATTEN

HEADLINE: 'Watch Your Step' vs. 'Step Right In'

BYLINE: By AMY GUNDERSON

 BODY:
ANXIOUS Americans planning a trip to Bolivia the first week of June were probably spending as much time surfing the Web as they were packing their suitcases. On June 1, amid reports of volatile street protests calling for President Carlos Mesa to resign, the United States State Department posted an advisory on its Web site telling visitors to ''consider the potential for disruptions.'' Six days later, with gas and food shortages in La Paz and just days before the country's new president, Eduardo Rodriguez, was appointed, the message from the State Department was much more direct: Don't go.
 The quick shuffling of advisories, as with Bolivia, isn't unusual. In May alone six travel warnings were issued, including a softening of advice for Colombia after a drop in violence in big cities like Bogota. That same month there were seven public announcements, generally considered less serious than travel warnings, including one for a tropical storm barreling toward Central America and another that warned of terrorist threats against Americans in Uzbekistan (later upgraded to a warning). 
 These days, if you are traveling anywhere even remotely off the beaten track, you've probably made a stop on the State Department's Web site, www.travel.state.gov, to check the consular information sheets, public announcements and travel warnings that alert travelers to anything from potential terrorist activity to the likelihood of a natural disaster. But tour operators and private security companies, as well as government officials from the countries listed, complain that the advice is often not timely, too broad or politically motivated. 
 Bruce McIndoe, the chief executive of iJet Intelligent Risk Systems, a security firm that advises corporations and individuals on travel risks, says that the advisories -- specifically the ''warnings'' category -- often tend to ''paint an entire country with a brush.
 ''Any country is diverse,'' Mr. McIndoe continued. ''I would be very confident of taking my family on safari in Kenya. I would not want to hang out in Nairobi too long.'' 
 James Dobbins, a former State Department official and now the director of the International Security and Defense Policy Center at the RAND Corporation, disputes that travel advisories are politically motivated but acknowledges that they are often put out with a just-in-case element. ''It's not a practical possibility for the government to ignore a threat even if a country might be annoyed by an advisory,'' Mr. Dobbins said. 
 And there certainly is an annoyance factor. Since the impact on tourism can be great, the release of an advisory is often greeted by political wrangling to get the advice reworded. For example, two years ago concerns about terrorist activity in Kenya prompted travel warnings from the United States and Britain urging visitors to defer nonessential travel there. Tour operators canceled trips, British Airways halted Kenya-bound flights and the number of American visitors dropped by 42 percent, according to the Kenya Tourist Board. 
 The British government has since canceled its warning but as of press time Kenya remained on the State Department's list. Though the advice was softened in May 2004, to encourage travelers to consider the risks of visiting Kenya rather than avoid it altogether, the Kenyan government, as well as tour operators, have been on a crusade to get the warning reclassified as a public announcement. But the risks in the country were not of a short-term nature, which would qualify it for a public announcement, said Angela Aggeler, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Consular Affairs of the State Department, who notes that travel warnings are typically reviewed every six months. 
 Many tour operators are baffled as to why the Kenya warning is there at all. ''One has to accept that the State Department may know more than the rest of us,'' said Dennis Pinto, managing director of Micato Safaris, which operates trips into Kenya's game parks. ''But after all the steps that have been taken to beef up security, it seems there is no valid reason for continuing it.''
 Despite the criticism, tour operators often do react swiftly to the notices. Butterfield & Robinson, which offers bicycling and hiking trips, has not gone to Nepal since 2001 because of American and Canadian travel alerts. Tauck World Discovery used to include a three-night stay in Bali as part of its Southeast Asia tour, but has not returned since the night club bombing in 2002. ''Bali is perfectly safe but there is a fairly strong wording on the advisory,'' said Scott Supernaw, Tauck's vice president for sales and marketing.
 Surprisingly, not much has changed since Sept. 11, 2001, in the way that the State Department has issued advisories. The biggest change in the system came more than a decade earlier when the government made it a policy to share with the public the travel information it was giving to diplomats.
 Britain, however, reviewed its travel advisories last spring. ''We wanted to be more descriptive than prescriptive,'' a spokesman for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office said. Notices are now more detailed and make a recommendation to not travel to all or parts of a country only if there is a major war, civil unrest, natural disaster or an extreme specific threat of terrorist activity. 
 While the lists of American, Canadian and British travel advisories contain many of the same countries, there are some noticeable differences. The United States encourages travelers to defer all nonessential travel to Indonesia, while Britain advises against travel to just certain regions of the country. Nepal and Egypt don't appear on any British travel warnings but do crop up on those of the United States and Canada. 
 That said, there are destinations with travel warnings that have done little to curb tourism interest. Geographic Expeditions has not made any changes to its 11-day trip to Bolivia in July, and Abercrombie & Kent is still planning to send travelers to Bolivia this fall. Travel restrictions to Libya were lifted last year, and since then, there has been a flood of interest, despite a warning that urges visitors to exercise caution when visiting the country. 
 Over time, some travel warnings start to lose their impact. Since the United States softened its language about Kenya last spring, travel has rebounded. Micato Safaris is reporting its best year ever, with trips to Kenya nearly sold out. Tauck is returning to Kenya next year. Yet there remains the push to have the State Department warning reclassified as a public announcement. ''Everyone has been pressuring for the U.S. to take another look at the situation,'' said Maisa Fernandez, spokeswoman for the Kenya Tourist Board. ''Right now, this is a pivotal time -- people are on pins and needles.'' 

WHETHER TO VISIT DEPENDS ON WHOSE ADVICE YOU'RE TAKING
 When is a country considered too dangerous for travelers? In some cases, the answer lies in the eye of the beholder, as different governments attach varying degrees of danger to different situations. Australia, Britain and Canada have gray areas built into their warning systems through the use of separate lists. For example, Australia (online at www.smartraveller.gov.au) has two main lists, one that discourages all travel and one addressing only ''essential travel''; Britain (www.fco.gov.uk) has four categories; Canada (www.voyage.gc.ca), nine. In addition to its travel warnings, the United States State Department's Bureau of Consular Affairs (www.travel.state.gov) issues public announcements, usually in effect for shorter periods than warnings, and consular information sheets for all countries. Details were current in mid-June. 

Bolivia -- The country was added to the United States list of travel warnings after recent episodes of political unrest. Americans are urged to ''defer nonessential travel.'' Britain advises against ''all but essential travel to parts'' of the country. Canada discourages travel to ''specified regions.'' The country does not appear on Australian warning lists.

Colombia -- The United States recently softened the language in its warning about ''threats, kidnappings and other violence,'' noting that ''violence has decreased markedly in most urban centers.'' Canada advises against all travel to most regions. Britain advises ''against all travel to parts'' of the country and Australia advises against ''nonessential travel'' there.

Ecuador -- Britain advises ''against all travel to parts'' of the country, citing a June 7, 2004, bombing at the British Consulate in Guayaquil. The United States, Canada and Australia have no warnings.

India -- The United States has issued neither a travel warning nor a public announcement, but travel to Jammu and Kashmir, except for the Ladakh region, is particularly discouraged in the consular information sheet. Australia does not list India. Britain and Canada have issued warnings, advising against visiting areas along the Pakistani border and northeastern areas near Myanmar.

Kenya -- Despite efforts by the Kenyan government to improve security after terrorist attacks there in 1998 and 2002 and the recent removal of Kenya from all warning lists by Britain, the State Department maintains its warning. Canada places Kenya on its list of countries in which Canadians should not visit ''specified regions.'' Australia does not place the country on a warning list. AUSTIN CONSIDINE

HEADLINE: In Buying A Home, You Are What You Do

BYLINE: By TERI KARUSH ROGERS

 BODY:
CONSCIOUSLY or not, Manhattanites tend to subscribe to the you-are-what-you-do-for-a-living notion. So perhaps it's not surprising that from the vantage of real estate brokers who shepherd, coax, bully and pander to them, an apartment-hunter's behavior can play out in striking sync with his or her occupation. 
 Take Wall Street types, dissected with greatest avidity by real estate brokers asked to serve up generalities. While bubble phobia is hardly uncommon in this market, it haunts financial professionals the most, brokers say.
''They always think that they're buying at the top, and they want to buy at the bottom,'' said Charles Russell, a senior vice president at the Corcoran Group who has worked on Wall Street as a petrochemicals broker. ''Every Wall Streeter I've worked with in the last five years, they say, 'I don't want to buy now, the bubble is about to burst,' and then they come back to me a year later and have to pay a million more for the same apartment.'' 
 Quantification is the name of the game for finance workers. ''Some bankers, every time they look at an apartment they like, they say, 'We've got to go home and put it on the spreadsheet,''' said Mitzie Lau, a Corcoran sales agent, echoing her peers. ''It is very funny because you start thinking: 'What else do they do with their life? Do they put everything on a spreadsheet?'''
 Ann M. Kim, an agent at Halstead Property, said all her finance clients look for the same information. ''When it comes down to putting their money in something, they're going to look at the yield basis, how much they're going to rent the property for if they were to move out, and what type of return they're going to get if they're going to own long term,'' she said.
 In drilling down through the quantitative bedrock, this type of buyer can be oblivious to the gut appeal of a place. Bruce Bennett, another Corcoran agent, recalled the middle-aged private banker to whom he showed a two-bedroom, $1.1 million apartment at Fifth Avenue and East 35th Street in January. The client peppered him with questions about the building's reserve fund, price per square foot and amperage in the kitchen. 
 ''This guy was buried into the listing looking into the numbers,'' Mr. Bennett said, but the client ignored the high-quality kitchen renovation and the south- and east-facing windows spilling sunshine into the corner dwelling. ''I said, 'Have you noticed the view?''' Mr. Bennett recalled. ''You have a Fifth Avenue address and Fifth Avenue view. He looked over and said, 'Oh, yeah, I guess that will be good for resale.'''
 Those who toil at hedge funds amass fortunes by leveraging little-known information. Perhaps as a result, they suffer from a ''need-to-know-more syndrome'' -- as in more than the broker -- when hunting for real estate, said Frederick W. Peters, president of Warburg Realty. He compared this typically young group with the similarly youthful mergers-and-acquisitions bankers he dealt with in the 1980's. 
 ''I'm not suggesting that the younger guys are disrespectful,'' Mr. Peters said. ''It's more that they're sure they know what is going to happen.'' He offered his merchant-banking clients, in their 40's and 50's, as a study in contrast. ''When I deal with people who are a little older, they're more comfortable knowing what they know and letting me know what I know,'' he said. ''They don't sweat the small stuff. They just decided that they want what they want and they're prepared to pay what it costs to get it. The whole issue of winning isn't in the picture so much.''
 The propensity among the hedge-fund set for making large bets -- combined with the Monopoly-money feel of overnight fortunes -- can translate into bidding-war gusto. Not so for lawyers, whose comparatively thin bank accounts accrete more incrementally and whose jobs often depend on negotiating a meeting of the minds.
 ''The idea that there's anything that should be non-negotiable is extremely hard for them to deal with,'' Mr. Peters said. ''A market like that of the first quarter, in which for many properties you only get to negotiate up, that's very hard for them.'' He added, ''The main thing about lawyers is they tend to be kind of hypervigilant, since they're trained to think about every contingency, and it's very hard for them to turn that off when they're dealing on their own account. So my experience with lawyers is that you have to get every detail nailed down.''
 In general, some brokers say, older lawyers who have achieved major career milestones are easier to work with, just as older Wall Street executives tend to revel less in a masters-of-the-universe persona than do rising stars. ''They know what they have to spend, what they want, and they'll negotiate but they're not unreasonable,'' said Susan Gerard, a broker at Halstead. ''The ones who can be the most unreasonable are the junior associates who have just gotten a taste of a good salary but haven't quite made their mark yet. I find they can be a lot more demanding. They can have a whole laundry list of demands that are not always rational.''
 On the bright side, lawyers excel at providing the sort of minutiae required for board packages, unlike those in the creative fields, who are said by brokers to be less practical-minded -- a minus when it comes to closing a deal, but a plus when finding a property to buy.
 ''Creatives are often more open on where they will go,'' said Kathleen M. Sloane, a vice president and director at Brown Harris Stevens. ''They're more apt to say: 'Can you find me a penthouse in Hell's Kitchen, or one anywhere that's quirky? We don't care about the location; we care about being at the top of the building and having light.' They would be willing to buy the penthouse to which the elevator doesn't go. They're willing to make sacrifices in their lives.''
 The subset of creatives known as celebrities can be surprisingly pleasant to work with, brokers say, once the phalanx of money managers and advisers is pierced and communication occurs directly with the client. Perhaps because they're accustomed to listening to advisers, this group is said to be more trusting. ''With people in finance, when the selling broker says they have another offer, the person in finance will always say, 'Do you believe that?''' said Wendy J. Sarasohn, a senior vice president at Corcoran ''whereas the creative people will trust it.''
 Buyers from the media industry often try to ''scoop'' their broker with unpublicized information about recent sales. Ms. Lau of Corcoran says: ''I think they do that because that's part of what they do every day, so even in their personal life they do the same thing. They always try to feel more justified and validated by something you don't know already.'' On the positive side, she said, ''If you get one media person you get a whole bunch, because they tend to talk a lot with their friends.''
 Doctors tend to be viewed by brokers as an amenable if not particularly high-flying group, with location -- near their practice -- among their biggest concerns. After a typically half-hearted attempt to negotiate a lower commission, they tend to undertake a deliberate search.
 ''They are very good about seeing all the apartments and they remember very well the details,'' Ms. Lau said. ''And then what they usually do is they tell you why they pass on the apartment rather than the other way around. It's sort of like a diagnosis. But once they find something they like, they really stick to it, because they've analyzed all the facts, but it takes them a little longer.'' 
 Yet once the diagnosis is made and a contract is signed, said Andrew A. Fine, president of the real estate brokerage A. Fine Company, doctors don't want to deal with the details. ''They tend to think about things for a long time,'' he said. ''And they seem to have an attitude that once they go into contract, they really don't want to deal with the details. They just want to snap their fingers and have it done.''
 Teachers pose a different kind of frustration for brokers. ''Teachers are kind of hard because they like to study everything,'' Ms. Lau said. ''I mean, they sometimes make you feel like you're the dumb one, because they take so long looking at a neighborhood that they even remember lines of the apartments and names of buildings and their numbers.'' On the other hand, she added, ''Once they find something they like that they can live with, they will not be nickel and diming the price.''
 On the subject of nickel-and-diming, such behavior is also infrequent among captains of industry, according to Leighton Candler, a senior vice president at Corcoran whose clients include a fair number of such figures. Not that this crowd moves very often. ''When you're in one of the rare, beautiful pieces of real estate in Manhattan, you don't give it up until you've found the one perfect thing that's a little different,'' Ms. Candler said.
 Stereotypes are just that, of course, with many exceptions to the rule. But the canniest brokers recognize that one person's stereotype is another's marketing tool. Mr. Bennett of Corcoran said he positions properties according to buyers' occupations. 
 ''If I know they come out of heavy-duty strategic, financial or analytical background, I start talking about what the building's financials are, the requirements financially they'll need to get into the building,'' Mr. Bennett said. ''If it's a person who is a touchy-feely kind, you know, who works in entertainment or creative writing or that kind of stuff, then I will go into the sunlight and the spaciousness of the space and how oversized the windows are.'' He added, ''When you position yourself that way, people end up thinking that you're very much connecting to them and listening to them.''
 And what of brokers turned buyers? Does their up-close view of others' peccadilloes translate into model buying behavior? Not by a long shot, says Mr. Peters of Warburg Realty, who has often observed the imperfect metamorphosis among his own agents.
 ''In general, the minute you put them in the position of being a buyer or a seller, they behave exactly like a buyer or a seller, and everything they know about the market goes completely out the window,'' said Mr. Peters, who has watched agents become huffy over routine board questions that suddenly seem invasive. ''I say that to them all the time -- 'You're acting like the client you wish you never had.'''
